(a)  It is unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any building or structure which encroaches upon any public street or property, or to erect any poles or wires or maintain any poles or wires over any public place, street, alley or other public place. 
(b)  No person shall erect, place or maintain in, upon or over any sidewalk, street, alley or other public place in the city, any fruit stand, shoe shining stand, flower stand, vegetable stand, lunch wagon, table box bin or other arrangement or structure for the display or sale of goods, wares or merchandise, or for the pursuit of any occupation whatsoever. 
(Res. No. 14-17, 11-18-2013) 
Sec. 42-215. - Smoking prohibited. 
Smoking is prohibited on the Barnard Street of the Glennville Downtown Business Area. Smoking is allowed only in the alleys located behind the downtown business area. 
(Res. No. 14-17, 11-18-2013) 
Sec. 42-216. - Use of public spaces and facilities. 
No person shall, without first submitting and receiving a permit from the city manager or his/her designee made according to the requirements set out hereinafter: 
(a)  Conduct a public assembly ,meeting, march, parade, demonstration, or other like event fixed or processional. 
(b)  Circulate or distribute any leaflets, handbills, notices, pamphlets, book, documents or papers of any kind on any public street, sidewalk or public place. 
(c)  Bring any non-domestic (e.g., any of the following would be considered non-domestic: poisonous, exotic, dangerous, feral, or farm animals) on, over or upon the public properties of the city, or facilities thereon. 
(d)  Station or erect any building, stand, bandstand, stage, tower, scaffold, sound stage, platform, rostrum or other structure on, over, or upon the public properties of the city. 
(e)  Create or emit any electronically amplified sound, on, over, or upon the public properties of the city, except from a radio, recorder or other device, which is possessed and used by an individual for his own enjoyment and is operated in such a manner so as to not interfere with the and enjoyment by any other person; or 
(f)  Conduct any exhibit, music, or dramatic performance, fair, circus, concert, play, radio or television broadcast, other than a news transmission on, over, or upon the public properties of the city; or station or use any electrical or electronic device or equipment that would require outdoor auxiliary power. 
(Res. No. 14-17, 11-18-2013) 
Sec. 42-217. - Event application. 
No less than 30 days prior to an event, the person associated in fact, whether or not a legally recognized entity, who wish to conduct an event requiring a permit, shall apply to the City of Glennville for an event permit. 
(Res. No. 14-17, 11-18-2013) 
Sec. 42-218. - Exhibition shows in street regulated. 
(a)  Defined. For the purposes of this section "exhibition show" shall mean an exhibition or show where merchandise, wares or other tangible items are displayed for show and/or sale either out of doors or in a building occupied in whole or part for a period not to exceed two days. It shall not include a sidewalk sale conducted by a merchant having a valid business license, on the sidewalk immediately adjoining said merchants' store. However, all sidewalk sales must be conducted so that reasonable use of the sidewalk is maintained for the normal pedestrian traffic. 
(b)  Permit required. No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or commence an exhibition show as defined above, in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place in the city unless an event permit has been obtained from the city. 
(c)  The producer of a special event shall be required to provide temporary outdoor toilet facilities for any event at which 200 or more persons are expected to be in attendance. The number of toilets and their locations shall be determined by the city code enforcement section. 
(d)  Persons wishing to use the street or sidewalks to conduct an event must present to the city a writing signed by an agent of his insurance carrier stating the person currently carries liability insurance in the amount equal to or exceeding $500,000.00, and that any accident or mishap occurring during the event is covered under the primary liability coverage. 
(e)  The producer of any special event shall hold harmless the city, its officers, employees and agents from liability of damages arising from any acts or omissions emanating from a special event. Proof of such wavier shall be filed with, and made a part of the application form. The producer shall be responsible for providing any and all other insurance that may be necessary for any special event. The amount and kind of insurance required shall be determined by the city manager, or his/her designee, after considering the nature of the special event, and the potential for harm and the degree of harm to persons and property. The producer shall provide proof to the city manager or his/her designee, that such insurance is in effect prior to the issue of a permit. 
(Res. No. 14-17, 11-18-2013) 
Sec. 42-219. - Cessation of activities. 
The safety, health, welfare and good order of all citizens and the community shall be first and foremost and every special event shall be conducted in such manner. The city manager, chief of police or code enforcement officer or their designee may terminate any activity, whether a part of or the entire event, which does not meet this community standard. Upon notification of the event producer in person by the city manager, chief of police or code enforcement officer to cease any activity, it shall be unlawful for such producer and/or any participants to permit such activity to continue. 
(Res. No. 14-17, 11-18-2013) 
Sec. 42-220. - Display of merchandise on sidewalks. 
It shall be permissible and lawful for merchants and dealers in various and sundry types of merchandise to display their merchandise on the sidewalk in front of their place of business provided such merchandise does not extend more than 27 inches from the front wall of the building occupied by the merchant or dealer (this area can be generally defined as the area of concrete located between the front wall of the building and the edge of the brick pavers), and provided the placing of such merchandise or articles for sale on the sidewalk does not interfere with the free and uninterrupted passage by the public along the sidewalk, and meets all state and federal regulations to include American Disabilities Act (ADA). No merchandise, articles for sale or other items shall be placed on or among any of the streets, alleys, sidewalks or passageways within the city if the placing of same will interfere with the free use and passage of the public along said street, alley, sidewalk or passageway. 
(a)  The merchant wishing to use the sidewalk for display of goods must present to the city a writing signed by an agent of his insurance carrier stating the merchant currently carries premises liability insurance in the amount equal to or exceeding $500,000.00 and that any accident or mishap occurring as a result of merchant displaying any wares, goods or merchandise of any kind upon any part of a city sidewalk is covered under the primary liability coverage. 
(b)  The merchant must execute an indemnity contract between himself and the city in which he agrees to indemnify and save harmless the city from any and all liability resulting from merchant's displaying any wares, goods, or merchandise of any kind upon any part of a city sidewalk. 
(c)  A merchant using city sidewalk pursuant to this section may use only that portion of the sidewalk directly in front of his own store, and may not in any way encroach upon the sidewalk frontage directly in front of any other store or business. 
(d)  Any items placed must be free of any lewd, racist or derogatory materials or images. 
(Res. No. 14-17, 11-18-2013) 
Sec. 42-221. - Posting. 
No person shall stick or post any handbill or placard of any description upon any public street light, electrical power poles, street signs, on vehicles, or any other structure without the permission of the property owner. 
(Res. No. 14-17, 11-18-2013) 
Sec. 42-222. - Signage. 
(a)  Permit required. Sign permits are required for all signs affixed to or hung from building, awning or structure. Permit applications are available in Glennville City Hall. 
(b)  Sidewalk signs in front of store fronts are authorized, provided the signs meet the follow conditions: 
(1)  Overall height not to exceed 60 inches tall and width not to exceed 27 inches wide. 
(2)  Contains no posters or print materials. 
(3)  Features no logos other than that of the business it promotes. 
(4)  Contain a chalkboard writing area (no dry-erase boards). 
(5)  Does not extend more than 27 inches from the front wall of the building (this area can be generally defined as the area of concrete located between the front wall of the building and the edge of the brick pavers), occupied by the merchant or dealer, and provided the placing of such signage on the sidewalk does not interfere with the free and uninterrupted passage by the public along the sidewalk, and meets all state and federal regulations to include American Disabilities Act (ADA). 
(6)  Items placed must be free of any lewd, racist or derogatory materials or images. 
(c)  All planned signage for downtown area must be reviewed and recommended by the downtown development authority prior to approval of the city. 
(Res. No. 14-17, 11-18-2013) 
Sec. 42-223. - Storefront awnings, painting and renovations. 
Prior to installing any awning, painting of exterior or renovation of any storefront, a permit must be obtained from city hall. All permits must be reviewed by the Glennville Downtown Development Authority which will make recommendations to the mayor and council for approval/disapproval. 
(Res. No. 14-17, 11-18-2013) 
Sec. 42-224. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Penalties for each violation of any item in articles II, III, IV or V, shall be as follows: 

 
The written warning for a first occurrence shall be hand delivered or mailed by first class mail and certified return receipt requested to the location of the house, dwelling unit or place of business prior to the issuance of a citation for violation of this article. Failure to make, deliver, mail or receive the first occurrence warning shall not affect any subsequent efforts or the penalty for any subsequent violation of this article. 
(b)  The violation of any provision of this article may be enjoined as a nuisance by issuing a citation for an article violation returnable to the city municipal court as referenced in section 1-11, General penalty; continuing violations. Such action may be maintained notwithstanding that other adequate remedies at law exist. 
(Res. No. 14-17, 11-18-2013) 
Chapter 46 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any subdivision plat or adopt any subdivision regulations saved from repeal, § 1-6(11); buildings and building regulations, ch. 10; community development, ch. 18; environment, ch. 22; floods, ch. 26; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 42; utilities, ch. 58; zoning, ch. 62; mobile or manufactured home parks, § 62-491 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 46-1. - Purpose and intent of chapter. 
The intent of having requirements and standards for subdivisions and planned unit developments are to: 
(1)  Provide a tool to implement the goals, objectives and policies of the comprehensive plan; 
(2)  Bestow flexibility and encourage innovation in the design of land development projects; 
(3)  Ensure the provision of public open spaces and building sites in land developments through the dedication or reservation of land for recreational, educational and other public purposes, using options for cluster developments where appropriate; 
(4)  Provide the means to develop land in a unified approach rather than a lot-by-lot approach; 
(5)  Preserve and protect natural resources; 
(6)  Provide safe, efficient and economical public services; and 
(7)  Promote affordable housing. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. I, § 102, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-2. - Interpretation of conflicting requirements. 
Whenever the requirements of this chapter conflict or are in any way inconsistent with the requirements of any other lawfully adopted statutes, rules, regulations, ordinances, the most restrictive, or that imposing higher standards, shall govern. No plat shall be approved or considered valid for any use or activity which is or would be otherwise illegal under the terms of any applicable local, state or federal law. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. I, § 103, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-3. - Legal conformity. 
The regulations of this chapter have been reviewed and found to be written in a legal format and in conformance with law by the city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. I, § 104, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-4. - Definitions. 
Except as specifically described in this section, all words shall have their customary dictionary meanings. The word "lot" includes "plot" or "parcel." The word "building" includes "structure." The word "should" expresses what is probable or expected. The word "used" or "occupied," as applied to any land or building, shall be construed to include the words "intended, arranged or designated to be used or occupied." The term "land use map" means the "city future land use map" as contained in the adopted county joint city-county comprehensive plan. Doubt as to the precise meaning of any word used in these regulations shall be clarified by the planning commission. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alley means a public way dedicated to and accepted by a governing body, providing a secondary means of access to abutting properties within a block. 
As-built plans means site plans depicting improvements made in any subdivision or planned unit development that were previously not accepted by the planning commission or the city council or that varied substantially from the preliminary or final plats previously submitted for review and approval. 
Base flood means any flood having a one percent chance of being equalled or exceeded in any given year. 
Block means a series of adjoining lots or a parcel of land entirely surrounded by public highways or streets, other than alleys or driveways. 
Buffer means a dense planting of shrubs and trees established and maintained to a height of not less than six feet on a strip of land not less than 20 feet in width; also includes areas along the course of any state waters that are required to be maintained in an undisturbed and natural condition. 
Building official means the individual who is appointed by the city manager to assist in enforcing and administering the development codes of the city. 
City council means the city council, which is the elected governing body. 
City manager means the city manager appointed by the city council. 
Cluster development means a residential subdivision within which individual lot sizes have been reduced to permit the creation of common open space maintained by a homeowner's association for the residents of the subdivision. 
Future land use map means the future land use map for the city as contained in the comprehensive plan; also referred to as the "land use map." 
Impervious surface means any area of land where the surface has been compacted to 98 percent or more, or has been covered with a layer of material (asphalt, concrete, brick or a structure containing a solid roof, floor, pad or foundation) that is similarly resistant to permeation by water. 
Land development means the division of a parcel of lot of record into two or more lots; the construction, reconstruction, conversion, structural alteration, relocation or enlargement of any building or other structure, or of any mining, excavation or landfill; and any change in the use of any building or other structure or land, or extension of the use of land. 
Lot means a parcel of land which satisfies the applicable area and dimensional requirements for the general zoning district within which it is located, or upon which exists a legal nonconforming use or structure and which has frontage along or legal access to a public street, and is intended as a unit for transfer of ownership or for land development. A recorded lot shall have a separate tax parcel reference number designated in the office of the county tax commissioner and/or the county tax assessor. 
Manufactured home means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length or, when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning and electrical systems contained therein; except that such term shall include any structure which meets all the requirements of this definition except the size requirements and, with respect to which, the manufacturer voluntarily files a certification required by the secretary of housing and urban development and complies with the standards established under the National Manufactured Home Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974, 42 USC 5401 et seq. 
Manufactured home park means any lot where manufactured homes are customarily parked for a longer period of time than 30 days for living or sleeping purposes, or where spaces are set aside and offered for rent for use by manufactured homes for living or sleeping purposes, including any land, building, structure or facility used by occupants of manufactured homes on such premises. 
Mobile home means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length or, when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and electrical systems contained therein and manufactured prior to June 15, 1976. 
Modular home means a factory fabricated transportable building consisting of units designed to be incorporated at a building site on a permanent foundation into a permanent structure to be used for residential purposes. 
Net density means an expression of a common measure indicating the ratio of the total developable land area of a proposed development project divided by the number of buildable lots or residential dwelling units. Total developable land area is the total land area of the proposed development site, less land dedicated for public improvements, areas of common use or areas of sensitive natural resources. 
Open space means a yard area which is not used for or occupied by a dwelling, driveway, off-street parking lot, loading space, drying yard or refuse storage space. 
Planned unit development (PUD) means a type of land use planning option which is intended to provide a more flexible approach to permitting for subdivisions and planned unit developments on a larger scale. Within the context of this chapter, four types of PUD options are permitted: 
(1)  Cluster residential subdivisions; 
(2)  Zero-side yard residential subdivisions; 
(3)  Mixed use developments; and 
(4)  Planned business centers. 
Planning commission means the city planning commission. 
Plat means a map, plan or layout of a proposed development site or subdivision indicating the location and boundaries of properties and the proposed land development activities. 
Private estate means a landed estate or real property whereby the owner of a lot or parcel who maintains a residence, and has a vested interest in a principal residential structure (consisting only of one existing single-family dwelling), may execute the grant of an interest to an heir, subject to conditional or qualified fee in the landed estate, to build, place, or otherwise develop one new single-family dwelling on the same lot, subject to the requirements of the applicable zoning district and other pertinent requirements of this chapter. 
Street means a dedicated and accepted public right-of-way which has been improved to provide a principal means of motor vehicle access to abutting properties. 
Structure means anything constructed or erected, the use of which requires a location on the ground, or attached to something having a location on the ground. The term structure shall refer specifically to a walled and roofed building, including a gas or liquid storage tank, that is principally above the ground, as well as a manufactured home. 
Subdivider means any person who undertakes the subdivision of land. 
Subdivision means any division of a tract or parcel of land into two or more lots, building sites or other divisions for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of sale, legacy or building development, and includes all divisions of land involving a new street or a change in existing streets, and includes resubdivision and, where appropriate to the context, relates to the process of subdividing or to the land or area subdivided; provided, however, that the following are not included in this definition: 
(1)  Any minor lot line adjustment of previously plat/planned lots where the total acreage of each lot affected is not increased and the resultant lots satisfy to the dimensional standards of these regulations; and 
(2)  The combination or recombination of portions of previously plat/planted lots where the total number of lots is not increased and the resultant lots satisfy the dimensional standards of these regulations. 
Subdivision, major, means a subdivision of land involving three or more new lots, and having three or more acres in developable land area, all which abut a dedicated and accepted road or street, or which involve new roads or streets or changes in existing rights-of-way. A major subdivision must adhere to the development requirements of this chapter. 
Subdivision, minor, means a subdivision of land involving three or fewer new lots, or less than three acres in developable area, all which abut a dedicated and accepted road or street, or which involve new roads or streets or changes in existing rights-of-way. 
Zoning district means a section of the city as established by this chapter within which the zoning regulations are uniform. 
Zoning ordinance means the zoning ordinance of the city. 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. II, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-5. - Effective date. 
The ordinance from which this chapter is derived shall take effect and be in full force from and after the date of its adoption by the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XV, § 1503, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-6. - Amendments. 
This chapter may be amended from time to time by the city. Before enacting any amendments, the city shall hold a public hearing thereon, at least 15 days prior to passage. Notice of the time and place of such a hearing shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XV, § 1504, 10-6-1998) 
Secs. 46-7—46-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLATS 

Sec. 46-41. - Platting jurisdiction and enforcement. 
(a)  Platting authority. The planning commission shall be the official plat/platting authority. 
(b)  Subdivision and planned unit development requirements. Any person proposing a major subdivision or planned unit development shall submit to the planning commission plat/plans and plans for a project of which shall conform to all the planned development requirements set forth in this chapter. 
(c)  Final plat/plan approval required prior to clearing and grading streets. No clearing or grading of any proposed streets shall begin prior to approval of the final plat/plan or preliminary plan by the planning commission as certified thereon. This prohibition shall extend to any other improvement related to the development of the proposed subdivision or planned development. 
(d)  Development plans approval required prior to construction of improvements. No subdivision or planned unit development improvement shall commence prior to the approval of development plans by the planning commission. 
(e)  Recording of final plat/plan/plan required prior to sale of lot. No landowner shall sell or negotiate the sale of any lot in a proposed subdivision or planned development by reference to or exhibition of or by any other use of plat/plan, plan, or such subdivision, until such plat/plan or plan has been given final approval by the planning commission, as certified thereon, and recorded in the office of the clerk of the county superior court. 
(f)  Submission of "as-built" plans prior to final acceptance by city council. Final acceptance of improvements in any subdivision which vary substantially from approved development plans shall not be given by the planning commission prior to the submission and approval of "as-built" plans and any other technical information which may be required. 
(g)  Legal status of public street required. No land dedicated as a public street shall be accepted, opened or improved, nor shall any utilities or other facilities be installed therein unless such street corresponds in its location and lines with a street shown on a plat/plan approved by the planning commission. Streets which shall have been accepted or opened as, or otherwise shall have received the legal status of a public street prior to the adoption of the ordinance from which the regulations of this chapter are derived may be improved, or utilities or other facilities may be installed therein. The city council, however, may locate and construct or may accept any other street, if the resolution or other measure for such approval is first submitted to the planning commission for its review and comment. 
(h)  Access to public street required. No building permit shall be issued for and no building or other structure shall be erected on any lot unless such lot has access to a street which shall have been accepted or opened, as, or otherwise shall have received the legal status of, a public street; provided, however, that private streets and other drive accessways may be approved under the terms of these rules and regulations in planned unit developments, condominium projects, apartment projects, townhouses, commercial developments, shopping centers or other developments. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. III, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-42. - Preapplication conference and applications of record. 
(a)  Preapplication review. A pre-application conference is intended to assist both the city and the applicant with regard to what type of application of record will be required for the proposed development activity. It also provides a means of exchanging information about the application process and how to develop land in conformance with the requirements and standards of this chapter. All pre-application conferences shall be governed by the following procedures: 
(1)  Voluntary and required preapplication conferences. There are two types of pre-application conferences, one type which is voluntary, and another which is required. They are distinguished as follows. No administrative or formal application or submissions are required to initiate a preapplication conference. 
a.  Voluntary. A voluntary pre-application conference may be arranged between the applicant and the building official or city manager for minor subdivisions, minor lot-line adjustments or re-combinations of previously plat/planted lots. 
b.  Required. A pre-application conference shall be required between the applicant and building official and the city manager for all major subdivisions and planned unit developments. 
(2)  Scope of consultation. Any discussions and recommendations that result from either type of pre-application conference shall be non-binding on the applicant and the city. Whenever a subdivision or planned unit development within the jurisdiction of the planning commission is proposed, the applicant may, at his discretion, consult early and informally with the building official or city manager for advice and assistance. The applicant may submit sketches and data, or a concept plan showing existing conditions within the site and in its vicinity and the proposed layout of the development. If the tract of land is not to be initially subdivided in its entirety, the applicant should provide sketches for the entire tract and indicate the proposed unit division of phased development boundaries. 
(3)  Recommendations. Should the applicant request a pre-application conference, the building official or city manager shall return any submitted sketch plans as quickly as possible and inform the applicant of areas where the proposed plans do not comply with the requirements set forth in these regulations. However, in no instance shall the pre-application conference be made or accepted in lieu of the required plat/plans and specifications contained herein. 
(b)  Administrative applications. Administrative applications may be submitted for minor subdivisions, a recombination of previously plat/planted lots, or minor lot line adjustments. The building official or city manager shall approve, disapprove, or otherwise reconcile administrative applications. The decision to approve an administrative application by the building official or city manager shall be made after consideration of all the relevant facts before him. Such relevant facts shall be measured to determine compliance with this chapter. The review procedures for an administrative application are as follows: 
(1)  Approval. If the proposed minor subdivision, recombination of previously plat/planted lots, or minor lot line adjustment as set forth in the application is in compliance with this chapter, the minor subdivision, lot recombination, or lot line adjustment shall then be recorded at the county clerk of court office. Final approval will be withheld pending confirmation to the city from the clerk of courts that the plat/plan has been filed. 
(2)  Disapproval. If the proposal submitted is not approved or otherwise reconciled, the reason for disapproval shall be stated in writing on the application. 
(3)  Reconciliation. Any administrative application that has been formally disapproved, or deemed incomplete or deficient by the building official or city manager, may be resubmitted for proper reconciliation. An additional application fee shall not be necessary for a re-submission. 
(4)  Review deadline. The building official or city manager shall issue a final determination regarding an administrative application within 30 days of the date that the application is complete and formally accepted by the building official or city manager (or designated agent) Failure by the building official or city manager to issue a final determination within the 30-day deadline shall constitute automatic approval of the application only if the applicant receives all other required local, state and federal approvals. 
(c)  Formal applications. The filing of a formal application is established to allow expedient and thorough review of larger scale development projects which are more complex and require substantial review. Major subdivisions and planned unit developments are subject to the formal application process. Review of formal applications shall be subject to the preliminary and final plat/plan procedures outline in sections 46-44 and 46-45. 
(d)  Coordination of review with other required local, state and federal reviews. The applicant shall be responsible for submitting applications to and receiving approval for any proposed development from other local, state and federal agencies as required by this chapter and all other applicable ordinances, regulations, and laws. At a minimum, the applicant shall submit copies of applications to such local, state and federal agencies along with the application information provided to the city. The planning commission may grant conditional approval for any municipal application upon approval by any and all local, state and federal agencies with jurisdiction to approve any aspect of the proposed development. An applicant shall not be issued a construction permit by the building official or city manager until such time that the applicant submits a copy of all required approvals from the applicable local, state and federal agencies. 
(e)  Special impact studies. During review of any application, the building official or city manager, the planning commission or the city council may determine that additional specific technical information regarding the project and its potential environmental, fiscal or traffic impacts is needed. If such a determination is made, the planning commission or the city council may condition approval of an application upon preparation of a special impact study intended to analyze the potential impacts of the development on the specific areas of concern. Where preparation of a special impact study has been required, no application shall be approved until such study has been submitted with adequate time provided for review. Typically, the responsibility and costs for such a study shall be borne by the applicant, unless municipal officials determine otherwise. 
(f)  Development construction phasing. Whenever a subdivision or planned unit development is proposed, the planning commission may require construction phasing, if it has been determined that there would be an undue burden on existing public infrastructure and facilities. Where it has been determined during the review of a subdivision or planned unit development application that a proposed development would exhaust or exceed the available capacity of existing public facilities including, but not limited to, roads, municipal water and sewer, fire protection, schools and police protection, the planning commission may require the applicant to submit a phased development schedule that shall demonstrate consistency and concurrency with the planning and installation of adequate public infrastructure and facilities to serve the affected development. 
(g)  Application and review fees. Application fees for the pre-application conference, minor applications, formal applications (tiers I, II and III) and plan/plat/plan changes and modifications will be assessed at the time of filing of a preliminary plat/plan/plan according to the schedule on file in the clerk's office. Any tier II or tier III formal application that involves development phasing as described in this chapter shall be subject to application and review fees for each submission of a preliminary plat/plan. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. IV, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-43. - Preliminary plat/plan procedures. 
(a)  Preliminary plat/plan application procedures. Upon completion of any voluntary or required pre-application conference, and after any determination is made, or action is taken (including subsequent application for re-zoning and approval thereof), leading to satisfactory conformance with zoning requirements, the applicant may submit an application for a preliminary plat/plan for consideration by the planning commission. A complete application shall be submitted to the building official or city manager at least 30 days prior to a regularly scheduled planning commission meeting. No formal application involving a preliminary plat/plan shall be accepted by the building official or city manager as complete unless it contains all of the documents required in section 46-42. The secretary of the building official or city manager or other designated official shall distribute copies of the submitted development plat/plan/plan to the members of the planning commission, and any other local government departments as necessary. 
(b)  Preliminary plat/plan review procedures. Upon determination by the building official or city manager that a submitted preliminary plat/plan is complete, the application shall be scheduled for review at the following regular meeting of the planning commission. The planning commission shall have 60 days from the date of the regular meeting to review the application and preliminary plat/plan for conformance with the applicable requirements of this chapter. In instances where the proposed development will be served by community or on-site sewage systems and/or water, the approval of the county health department shall be received prior to approval of the preliminary plat/plan by the planning commission. If the planning commission fails to approve or deny the application within the required 30 day review period and the applicant receives all other required local, state, and federal approvals, the preliminary plat/plan shall be deemed to have been approved. 
(c)  Preliminary plat/plan review period extensions. The applicant and the planning commission may mutually agree to extend the time period for approval or denial of a preliminary plat/plan for a period not to exceed 30 days to allow additional time for the preparation of special impact studies and/or major changes to the application. 
(d)  Expiration of an approved preliminary plat/plan. A preliminary plat/plan approved or conditionally approved by the planning commission shall expire and be of no further effect 180 days from the date of the approval, unless the applicant submits a written request for time extension to the planning commission clearly stating the need for the extension. When such a request has been received, the planning commission may extend the approval for not more than an additional 180 days. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. V, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-44. - Preliminary plat/plan specifications. 
(a)  Specifications Each preliminary plat/plan shall be accompanied by five copies of the plat/plan prepared in compliance with the following specifications: 
(1)  Drafting specifications. The preliminary plat/plan shall be clearly and legibly drawn on suitable permanent reproducible material. The scale shall be 100 feet to one inch on sheets of 36 inches by 24 inches. If the complete plat/plan or plan cannot be shown on one sheet of this size, it may be shown in sections on more than one sheet with an index map at a reduced scale. A reproduction of the original tracing must be submitted. 
(2)  Additional specifications. Additional specifications are as follows: 
a.  Ground elevations at two-foot contours. 
b.  Proposed name of subdivision. 
c.  North point and graphic scale and date. 
d.  Vicinity map showing location and acreage of the subdivision. 
e.  Primary control points with necessary descriptions and locations of such angles, bearings, and similar data necessary for proper location. 
f.  Names and owners of record of adjoining land. 
g.  Existing streets, utilities and easements on and adjacent to the tract. 
h.  Proposed layout including streets and alleys with proposed street names, lot lines with approximate dimensions, easements, lands to be reserved or dedicated for public uses and any land to be used for purposes other than single-family dwellings. 
i.  Block numbers and lot numbers. 
j.  Provisions for water supply, sewerage and drainage. 
k.  Minimum building setbacks on all lots and other sites. 
l.  Such street cross sections and centerline profiles as may be required by the chapter. 
(b)  Certificate of preliminary approval. Upon approval of the preliminary plat/plan by the planning commission, the following certification shall be placed on the plat/plan: 
"I certify that all the requirements for preliminary approval of this plat/plan/plan have been fulfilled in accordance with the regulations of the City of Glennville, Georgia, and the requirements of the City of Glennville planning commission. 
Name ____________ , chair (secretary) of (for the chair of) the City of Glennville planning commission. 
Date: ____________ / ____________ / ____________ " 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. VI, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-45. - Final plat/plan procedures. 
(a)  Review. Upon determination by the building official or city manager that a submitted final plat/plan is complete, the application shall be scheduled for review by the planning commission at the following regular meeting. The planning commission shall have 30 days from the date of the regular meeting to review the application and/or final plat/plan for conformance with the applicable requirements of this chapter. In instances where the proposed development will be served by community or on-site sewage systems and/or water, the approval of the county health department shall be received prior to approval by the planning commission. If the planning commission fails to approve or deny the application within the required 30-day review period and the applicant receives all other required local, state and federal approvals, the application shall be deemed as approved, and advanced to the next stage of review or recording. 
(b)  Review period extensions. The applicant and the planning commission may mutually agree to extend the time period for the review, approval or denial of a formal application for a period not to exceed 30 days to allow additional time for the preparation of special impact studies and/or major changes to the application. 
(c)  Planning commission approval. The planning commission may give final approval of final plat/plans subject to any special conditions as authorized by this chapter, provided that the proposed development and the final development plat/plan conforms to the requirements of this chapter. If the application for a final development plat/plan is approved, the planning commission shall sign a certificate of approval on all final plat/plans. Recording of the final plat/plan/plan shall be done in accordance with this section. 
(d)  Planning commission disapproval. The planning commission may find the final plat/plan in conflict with the regulations of this chapter, requiring the disapproval of the final plat/plan. A statement of the reasons for disapproval shall be placed on five copies of the final plat/plan/plan with one copy being returned to the subdivider, one copy to the county health department, one copy to the fire chief, one copy to the building official or city manager, and one copy being attached to the records of the planning commission. The original plat/plan shall be returned to the applicant. In addition, the minutes of the planning commission shall reflect the reasons for denial and record the individual vote of the members. No construction permit shall be issued to an applicant who has been denied approval of a development application. Any applicant who has been denied approval by the planning commission may appeal the decision to the board of adjustment or resubmit a new application in compliance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. VII, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-46. - Final plat/plan specifications. 
Each final plat/plan application shall be accompanied by five copies of the plat/plan prepared in compliance with the preliminary plat/plan and the following specifications: 
(1)  Original tracing specifications. The final plat/plan or plan shall be clearly and legibly drawn on suitable permanent reproducible material. The scale shall be 100 feet to one inch on sheets of 36 inches by 24 inches. If the complete plat/plan or plan cannot be shown on one sheet of this size, it may be shown in sections on more than one sheet with an index map at a reduced scale. A reproduction of the original tracing must be submitted. 
(2)  Additional specifications. The final plat/plan or plan shall contain the following information: 
a.  Primary control points with necessary descriptions and locations of such angles, bearings and similar data necessary for proper location. 
b.  Tract boundary lines, right-of-way lines of streets, easements and property lines of residential lots and other sites with sufficient data to determine readily and to reproduce on the ground the location, bearing and length of every street line, lot line, boundary line and setback line, whether curved or straight. This shall include, but not be limited to, the radius, length of arc, internal angles, and bearing of the tangents and tangent distances for the centerline of curbed streets and curved property lines that are not the boundary or curved streets. All dimensions shall be given to the nearest 1/100 of a foot, and all angles shall be given to the nearest minute. 
c.  Name and right-of-way width of each street or other right-of-way. 
d.  Location, dimensions and purpose of any easements. 
e.  Block numbers and lot numbers. 
f.  Purpose for which sites, other than residential lots, are dedicated or reserved. 
g.  Minimum building setback lines on all lots and other sites. 
h.  Location and description of monuments and markers. 
i.  Names and owners of record of adjoining land. 
j.  Reference to recorded subdivision plat/plans of adjoining plat/planted land by record and name. 
k.  Title, numerical scale, north arrow, and date. 
l.  Certification by the building official or city manager that the developer has complied with one of the following alternatives: 
1.  All improvements have been installed in accordance with the requirements of this chapter and other applicable regulations; or 
2.  A performance bond has been approved and accepted by the city council in sufficient amount to ensure the completion of all required improvements in accord with the requirements of this chapter. 
Notation of the necessary certifications shall be placed on the final plat/plan as specified below. 
m.  Engineer's or surveyor's certification: A signed certification by a registered state professional engineer certifying to the accuracy of the survey and the plat/plan shall be placed on the final plan or plat/plan as follows: 
"In my opinion this plan/plat/plan is a correct representative of the land plat/planted and has been prepared in conformity with the minimum standards and requirements of law and has been calculated for closure by latitudes and departures and is found to be accurate within one foot in ____________ feet. 

 
n.  Owner's certification: A signed certification of ownership shall be placed on the final plat/plan as follows: 
"Owner's Certification:  State of Georgia, County of Tattnall. 
"The undersigned certifies that he is the owner of the land shown on his plat/plan/plan and acknowledges this plat/plan and allotment to be his free act and deed and dedicates to public use forever all areas shown or indicated on this plat/plan as streets, alleys, easements or parks. 

 
o.  Health department certification: A signed certification of the county health department shall be placed on the final plat/plan/plan in every instance except when the subdivision is developed with a public sanitary sewer system and/or public water. 
"I certify that the general lot layout shown on this plat/plan/plan has been approved by the Tattnall County Health Department for development with…. 

 
NOTE: The blanks in the above certification statement shall be completed by the director of the health department, or his representatives, to indicate whether approval is based upon the use of individual sewer systems, individual water supplies, a community sewer system, a community water supply, or a combination thereof. 
p.  Certification of final approval by planning commission: Certification of final approval by the planning commission shall be placed on the final plat/plan/plan only after every item of this regulation has been complied with and shall state the following: 
"I certify that all the requirements for final approval of this plat/plan/plan have been fulfilled in accordance with the regulations of the City of Glennville, Georgia, and the requirements of the City of Glennville Planning Commission. 
"Name ____________ , Chairman (Secretary) of (for the Chairman of) the City of Glennville Planning Commission. 
Date: ____________ / ____________ / ____________ " 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. VIII, 10-6-1998) 
Secs. 46-47—46-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DESIGN REQUIREMENTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 46-81. - General design requirements. 
(a)  Land suitability. The selection of an area for any subdivision or planned unit development should be located strategically on lands that are suitable for the types of development proposed. Factors relevant to selection of an area for subdivision or planned development shall be considerate of land use related criteria stated in section 62-119. Other factors shall include, but not be limited to, the suitability of land as it relates to flooding, proper drainage, steep slopes, bedrock, topography, utility easements or other features or problems which may create unfavorable development conditions. 
(b)  General site design guidelines. The proposed development must be designed so as to produce an environment of stable and desirable character not out of harmony with the surrounding neighborhood. The review by the planning commission shall consider the following design elements: 
(1)  Privacy. Personal and individual privacy shall be maintained and balanced with the provision of public and common areas. 
(2)  Variety. Interest and variety shall be sought by means of street design and changes in and mixtures of building types, heights, facades, setbacks, planting, or size of open space. The design shall be harmonious as a whole and not simply from street-to-street. 
(3)  Traffic and parking. Through or commercial traffic should not be encouraged within a subdivision or a planned unit development of less than 20 acres. Proposed local or internal streets should curve to discourage the fast movement of traffic. Shared parking facilities shall be encouraged where the same parking spaces can be utilized by two or more different land uses. Group parking areas should be screened so that vehicles are substantially hidden from the street. 
(4)  Flexibility. Modification of either development intensity or basic dimensional standards shall be permitted under the options provided for under planned unit development standards and those as determined by the planning commission. 
(c)  Naming requirements. 
(1)  Street naming. The purpose of naming streets is to provide an orderly process for identifying geographic areas and for orienting users of the street system. Naming requirements for streets shall be observed as follows: 
a.  Approval. Street names and address numbers shall be subject to the approval of the building official or city manager. 
b.  Duplication of names. Street names shall not duplicate nor be closely approximated phonetically to any name of an existing city street or road. 
c.  Continuity of names. Any street or road which is a continuation, an approximation or logical continuation of any existing dedicated street or road or shall bear the same name. 
d.  Small culs-de-sac. Small culs-de-sac which have less than five interior lots may be omitted for name purposes, when the house numbers are continuous with those of the street or road to which they have access. 
e.  Street name designations. Street name designations shall be used as follows: 
1.  Boulevard or parkway: shall be reserved for streets or roads designated on the highway classification map which are planned to have a median divider of sufficient size to allow for landscaping. 
2.  Avenue or road: shall be reserved for streets or roads of substantial continuity such as major or minor arterials designated on the highway classification map. 
3.  Street or drive: shall be reserved for streets of less continuity such as collector streets and roads as designated on the highway classification map. 
4.  Court, place, circle, way or terrace: shall be reserved for streets and/or roads with no continuity. 
(2)  Name of subdivision or planned unit development. Any proposed name for a subdivision or planned unit development shall not duplicate, or too closely approximate phonetically, the name of any other subdivision or planned unit development. The planning commission shall have final authority to designate the name of a subdivision or planned unit development which shall be determined upon acceptance of the concept plan. 
(d)  Access. 
(1)  Intent. All subdivisions and planned unit developments shall provide adequate public access for street, utility, and pedestrian systems which shall be designed and constructed to facilitate efficient movement and circulation, to ease congestion, and to promote safety. 
(2)  Design standards. Where a major subdivision or planned unit development borders on or contains an existing proposed primary arterial, the planning commission may require that access to such streets be limited by one of the following means: 
a.  Subdivided lots bordering a primary arterial shall back onto the primary arterial and front onto a parallel local street. No access to these types of lots shall be provided from the primary arterial, and screening in the form of a buffer or screen shall be provided in a strip of land along the rear property line of such lots. 
b.  Where there exists a marginal access or service road separated from the primary arterial, a planting or a grass strip shall be established and maintained and there shall be access thereto at appropriate points. 
c.  The development shall have at least two entrances from a public street that are at least 100 feet apart (as measured from accessway centerline to accessway centerline along the intersecting street line). The planning commission may require additional accessways as it deems necessary to accommodate safe entrance, egress, and emergency access to the development, and for the purpose of accommodating emergency, rescue, or other critical public safety vehicles. 
(e)  Comprehensive plan consistency. All subdivisions and planned unit developments, and those requirements and standards that apply are intended to serve as a device to further the goals, objectives and policies of the comprehensive plan. The review of a subdivision or planned unit development provides a comprehensive means of addressing a wide range of issues for a broad geographic area. The use of a theme or development concept will provide a basis for relating the proposed development request to standards provided for in all municipal land development regulations and the comprehensive plan. The policies of the comprehensive plan's land use element, including the future land use map, in conjunction with the preceding policies of other comprehensive plan elements, shall form the basis for reviewing proposed planned unit developments. 
(f)  Modification of zoning standards for planned unit developments. The basic design and dimensional standards provided for each zoning district by the city zoning chapter for any planned unit development may be modified on the recommendation of the building official or city manager to the planning commission (and as applicable the city council), so that the property under consideration may be developed in a reasonable manner and without detriment to the public welfare and interest. Any modification is subject to review of a preliminary and/or final plat/plan, or a revised development plan. Modifications may be authorized by the planning commission to facilitate and promote innovative design options. Such innovative design options include the following: 
(1)  Cluster residential development option. The purpose for cluster development is to provide flexibility and options in planned unit development design. The objectives of cluster development are to create an improved living environment which is varied, functional, cost effective, aesthetically pleasing, and capable of preserving the unique natural, physical, or cultural features of a site. Any planned unit development utilizing the cluster development option is subject to the provisions set forth in this section. Upon receipt of the recommendation of the building official or city manager, the planning commission shall determine whether a proposed cluster development complies with all the objectives, requirements and standards of this section. All cluster developments shall comply with the following general requirements: 
a.  Development intensity. The development intensity for a cluster development shall not exceed standards and requirements for the applicable zoning district is located, as applied to the developable land area of the proposed development site. However, an increase in development intensity on a portion or portions of the property may be allowed through a reduction in required lot sizes, as long as any resulting residual land is preserved as common open space as specified in the zoning chapter. 
b.  Density bonus. The planning commission may allow an increase in permissible development intensity of not more than ten percent if the proposed cluster development will result in substantial recreational improvements to the developable portions of the common open space. Substantial recreation improvements shall include, but not be limited to: 
1.  Jogging/walking trails with exercise stations and benches and landscaping where appropriate. 
2.  Ball fields, tennis courts, or basketball courts. 
3.  Landscaped picnic area with tables, shelters and grills/pits for cooking. 
4.  An outdoor swimming pool with protective fences. 
5.  A clubhouse or other common indoor activity center. 
A density bonus consistent with these provisions also may be granted if the open space will be designed to protect and preserve any rare or endangered plant or species habitat on the property. Finally, the planning commission, upon recommendation of the building official or city manager, may grant a ten percent density bonus if at least half of the bonus dwelling units will be permanently priced such that they can be afforded by a household earning 80 percent of the county's median household income. Where the density bonus is related to the provision of affordable housing units, appropriate restrictive covenants shall be placed on the affordable units to ensure that they will remain permanently affordable. Also, the planning commission may require that the designated affordable bonus housing units be distributed at random throughout the development to ensure that the affordable units are constructed and maintained in a manner commensurate with the market rate units. In determining the amount of density bonus to be extended for the aforementioned optional improvements, the planning commission may consider other factors including, but not limited to, those specified in section 46-46(2). 
c.  Minimum size. A cluster development shall consist of not less than 20 dwelling units, unless the development is considered by the planning commission to be a logical extension of an existing or approved cluster development and will be designed to be compatible with said neighboring development. 
d.  Types of dwellings. A cluster development may consist of a mix of all residential dwelling unit types permitted within the applicable zoning district. 
e.  Open space. All open space shall be integrated into the development design such that it enhances the privacy and convenience of individual homes within the development. At no point shall an open space be less than 25 feet in width. 
f.  Buffers. All buffers shall comply with standards specified in the city zoning chapter. However, the planning commission may require a buffer strip of at least 25 feet along any or all property boundaries to provide a natural separation between different housing types. Any required buffer shall be permanently vegetated and maintained as common open space. No designated buffer strip may be improved in order to acquire a density bonus. 
g.  Public utilities, infrastructure, easements. All public utilities, infrastructure, easements and access requirements shall be provided as specified under by this chapter. 
h.  Drainage. The planning commission may require the construction of stormwater detention or retention areas within cluster developments to prevent runoff and erosion and sedimentation impacts on neighboring developments. Where such drainage improvements are required, adequate maintenance provisions shall be included in the restrictive covenants, association bylaws or city development regulations. Any stormwater detention or retention areas shall be considered open spaces; however, they must be maintained in a natural or vegetated state, and they may not be used to satisfy the 50 percent developable land area requirement for open space within the development, as required in the city zoning chapter. 
i.  Maintenance of common areas. Every cluster development shall include provisions for maintenance of all areas within the development under common ownership. 
j.  Pedestrian access. Where a proposed cluster development contains multiple improved recreational facilities, adequate provision for safe pedestrian access to such facilities and open space areas shall be provided. The planning commission may require sidewalks for any cluster development if the potential traffic volumes and pedestrian activity warrant such improvements or if the development represents an extension or expansion of an adjoining residential development that contains sidewalks. Furthermore, any proposed or required sidewalks within a cluster development shall tie into existing public sidewalks that adjoin the proposed development. 
k.  Compliance with state laws. All units within a cluster development under common ownership shall satisfy all applicable regulations of the "Georgia Condominium Act" (O.C.G.A. § 44-3-70 et seq.). 
l.  Dimensional requirements. Cluster developments shall be constructed in accordance with the preliminary plat/plan as approved by the planning commission. Within a cluster development, the planning commission may authorize the following changes to dimensional requirements: 
1.  Lot size reductions. The maximum reduction in lot sizes shall not exceed 35 percent in any zoning districts. 
2.  Lot width reductions. The maximum percentage reduction in required lot widths shall be the same as for lot sizes in the respective zoning districts. 
3.  Coverage and impervious surface ratios. The maximum lot coverage shall be 30 percent for each lot in all cluster developments. In addition, no more than 40 percent of all land within the cluster development may be covered by impervious surfaces, including roads, sidewalks, paved parking areas, and structures. 
4.  Front yard requirements. The minimum permitted front yard setback shall be 25 feet. No reduction in front yard setbacks shall be allowed for lots fronting on a collector or arterial highway. 
(2)  Zero lot line option. Upon review and approval by the planning commission, the side yard setback requirements for single-family (detached) dwelling lots may be reduced to allow a zero side yard setback on one side of a lot, provided that the following conditions are met: 
a.  Any reduction in one side yard requirement shall result in a corresponding increase in the side yard requirement for the opposite side yard. In this manner, the overall side yard requirement of the district shall be met. 
b.  Front yard, rear yard and corner side yard requirements of the general zoning district shall not be modified. 
c.  Side yard setback requirements shall not be modified for an individual lot unless it is part of a block in which each lot's side yard setback is to be modified. The arrangement of modified side yard requirements shall allow for an open side yard area between each dwelling unit. 
d.  The zero lot line provisions shall not apply to accessory buildings that are not attached to the primary residential structure. 
e.  The developer of a subdivision for which modifications to the side yard setback requirements are requested shall furnish to the planning commission a copy of proposed deed restrictions, conditions or covenants. Such covenants shall include as minimum provisions: 
1.  A maintenance easement of at least four feet in width, which will allow for the maintenance of exterior dwelling walls facing a zero setback line. 
2.  A requirement that dwelling walls facing a zero setback be windowless. 
(3)  Mixed use development option. The purpose for a mixed use development option is to encourage the development of large tracts of land as planned communities or neighborhoods; to preserve natural features; to encourage efficient development of land and public improvements; and to promulgate flexible and innovative design options. A mixed use development option allows a variety of land uses under the premise that, in the collective, each differing land use has an orderly relationship to one another. 
a.  Development intensity. The development intensity for a mixed use development shall not exceed standards and requirements for the applicable zoning district in which it is located, as applied to the developable land area of the proposed development site. However, an increase in development intensity on a portion or portions of the property may be allowed through a reduction in required lot sizes, as long as any resulting residual land is preserved as common open space as specified in the city zoning chapter. 
b.  Density bonus. The planning commission may allow an increase in permissible development intensity of not more than ten percent if the proposed mixed use development will result in substantial public improvements. Substantial public improvements shall include, but not be limited to: 
1.  Innovative parking lot design encouraging landscaping and pedestrian access. 
2.  Where residential uses are proposed, if at least 20 percent of the dwelling units will be permanently priced such that they can be afforded by a household earning 80 percent of the county's median household income. Where the density bonus is related to the provision of affordable housing units, appropriate restrictive covenants shall be placed on the affordable units to ensure that they will remain permanently affordable. Also, the planning commission may require that the designated affordable bonus housing units be distributed at random throughout the development to ensure that the affordable units are constructed and maintained in a manner commensurate with the market rate units. In determining the amount of density bonus to be extended for the aforementioned optional improvements, the planning commission may consider factors such as those specified in section 62-119. 
c.  Open space. Every mixed use development shall contain common open space equal in area to the total area reduction in individual lot sizes. At a minimum, all open spaces provided shall be in compliance with the city zoning chapter. All open space shall be integrated into the development design such that it enhances the compatibility of land uses within the development. At no point shall an open space be less than 25 feet in width. 
d.  Buffers. All buffers shall comply with standards specified in the city zoning chapter. However, the planning commission may require a buffer strip of at least 50 feet along any or all property boundaries to provide a natural separation between different land uses. Any required buffer shall be permanently vegetated and maintained as common open space. No designated buffer strip may be improved in order to acquire a density bonus. 
e.  Public utilities, infrastructure, easements. All public utilities, infrastructure, easements and access requirements shall be provided as specified by this chapter. 
f.  Drainage. The planning commission may require the construction of stormwater detention or retention areas within mixed use developments to prevent runoff, erosion, and sedimentation impacts on neighboring developments. Where such drainage improvements are required, adequate maintenance provisions shall be included in the restrictive covenants, association bylaws, or rules for the development as prescribed in city development regulations. Any stormwater detention or retention areas shall be considered open spaces; however, they must be maintained in a natural or vegetated state, and they may not be used to satisfy the 50 percent developable land area requirement for open space within the development, as required in the city zoning chapter. 
g.  Maintenance of common areas. Every mixed development shall include provisions for maintenance of all areas within the development under common ownership. 
h.  Pedestrian access. Where a proposed cluster development contains multiple improved recreational facilities, adequate provision for safe pedestrian access to such facilities and open space areas shall be provided. The planning commission may require sidewalks for any mixed use development if the potential traffic volumes and pedestrian activity warrant such improvements or if the development represents an extension or expansion of an adjoining residential development that contains sidewalks. Furthermore, any proposed or required sidewalks within a mixed use development shall tie into existing public sidewalks that adjoin the proposed development. 
i.  Dimensional requirements. Mixed use developments shall be constructed in accordance with the preliminary plat/plan as approved by the planning commission. Within a mixed use development, the planning commission may authorize the following changes to dimensional requirements: 
1.  Lot size reductions. The maximum reduction in lot sizes shall not exceed 25 percent in all applicable zoning districts. 
2.  Lot width reductions. The maximum percentage reduction in required lot widths shall be the same as for lot sizes in the respective zoning districts. 
(4)  Planned business center option. The purpose for a planned business center option is to provide for a range of professional, administrative, research and manufacturing uses; the operation of which is quiet and clean in order to preserve natural features; to encourage efficient development of land and public improvements; and to promulgate flexible and innovative design options. This option allows a variety of non-residential and non-commercial land uses under the premise that, in the collective, each differing land use has an orderly relationship to one another. 
a.  Development intensity. The development intensity for a planned business center shall not exceed standards and requirements for the applicable zoning district, in which it is located, as applied to the developable land area of the proposed development site. However, an increase in development intensity on a portion or portions of the property may be allowed through a reduction in required lot sizes, as long as any resulting residual land is preserved as common open space as specified in the city zoning chapter. 
b.  Density bonus. The planning commission may allow an increase in permissible development intensities (including floor area and impervious surface ratios) of not more than ten percent if the proposed planned business center will provide for substantial public improvements. Substantial public improvements shall include, but not be limited to: 
1.  Innovative parking lot design encouraging landscaping and pedestrian access. 
2.  Jogging/walking trails with exercise stations and benches and landscaping where appropriate. 
3.  Landscaped picnic area with tables, shelters and grills/pits for cooking. 
4.  A clubhouse or other common indoor activity center. 
c.  Open space. Every planned business center shall contain common open space equal in area to the total area reduction in individual lot sizes. At a minimum, all open spaces provided shall be in compliance with the city zoning chapter. All open space shall be integrated into the development design such that it enhances the compatibility of land uses within the development. At no point shall an open space be less than 25 feet in width. 
d.  Buffers. All buffers shall comply with standards specified in the city zoning chapter. However, the planning commission may require a buffer strip of at least 50 feet along any or all property boundaries to provide a natural separation between different land uses. Any required buffer shall be permanently vegetated and maintained as common open space. No designated buffer strip may be improved in order to acquire a density bonus. 
e.  Public utilities, infrastructure, easements. All public utilities, infrastructure, easements and access requirements shall be provided as specified under this chapter. 
f.  Drainage. The planning commission may require the construction of stormwater detention or retention areas within planned business center to prevent runoff, erosion, and sedimentation impacts on neighboring developments. Where such drainage improvements are required, adequate maintenance provisions shall be included in the restrictive covenants, association bylaws, or city development regulations. Any stormwater detention or retention areas shall be considered open spaces; however, they must be maintained in a natural or vegetated state, and they may not be used to satisfy the 50 percent developable land area requirement for open space within the development, as required in the city zoning chapter. 
g.  Maintenance of common areas. Every planned business center shall include provisions for maintenance of all areas within the development under common ownership. 
h.  Pedestrian access. Where a proposed cluster development contains multiple improved recreational facilities, adequate provision for safe pedestrian access to such facilities and open space areas shall be provided. The planning commission may require sidewalks for any mixed use development if the potential traffic volumes and pedestrian activity warrant such improvements or if the development represents an extension or expansion of an adjoining residential development that contains sidewalks. Furthermore, any proposed or required sidewalks within a mixed use development shall tie into existing public sidewalks that adjoin the proposed development. 
i.  Dimensional requirements. Planned business centers shall be constructed in accordance with the preliminary plat/plan as approved by the planning commission. Within a planned business center, the planning commission may authorize the following changes to dimensional requirements: 
1.  Lot size reductions. The maximum reduction in lot sizes shall not exceed ten percent in all applicable zoning districts. 
2.  Lot width reductions. The maximum percentage reduction in required lot widths shall be the same as for lot sizes in the respective zoning districts. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. IX, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-82. - General requirements for streets and rights-of-way. 
All new streets constructed as a result of a subdivision or a planned unit development shall conform to the following standards: 
(1)  Topography and arrangement. Roads shall be related appropriately to the topography. Grades of streets shall conform as closely as possible to the original topography. A combination of steep grades (eight percent or greater) and curves shall be avoided. Proposed streets shall be extended to the boundary lines of the tract to be developed under planned requirements, unless prevented by topography or other physical conditions. All streets shall be properly integrated with the existing county road and street system. The use of curvilinear streets, culs-de-sac, or U-shaped streets shall be encouraged where such use shall result in a more desirable layout. 
(2)  Existing streets. Existing streets shall be continued at the same or greater width, but in no case less than the required width. 
(3)  Frontage on improved roads. No planned unit development shall be approved unless the area to be developed shall have frontage on and access from an existing dedicated public street or road. 
(4)  Reserve strips. The creation of reserve strips shall not be permitted adjacent to a proposed street in such a manner to deny access from adjacent property to such street. 
(5)  Street jogs. Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 200 feet shall not be permitted, unless the intersected street has separated dual lanes without median breaks at either intersection. 
(6)  Grading and improvement plan. Roads shall be graded and improved and shall conform to local construction standards and specifications, and shall be approved as to design and specifications in accordance with appropriate plat/plan approval. 
(7)  Intersections. Unless otherwise noted, required distances between streets shall be measured from centerline-to-centerline. The following standards shall also apply: 
a.  Streets shall be laid out to intersect as nearly as possible at right angles. A proposed new intersection of two new streets at an angle of less than 75 degrees shall not be acceptable. An oblique street should be curved approaching an intersection and should be approximately at right angles for at least 100 feet from the end of the curve to the street intersection. Not more than two streets shall intersect at any one point, unless specifically approved by the planning commission. 
b.  Proposed new intersections along one side of an existing street shall coincide with any existing intersections on the opposite side of such street. Where streets intersect major streets, their alignments shall be continuous. Intersection of major streets shall be at least 800 feet apart. 
c.  Minimum curb radius at the intersection of two local streets shall be at least 20 feet; and minimum curb radius at an intersection involving a collector or arterial street shall be at least 25 feet. 
d.  Intersections shall be designed at a flat grade wherever practical. In hilly or rolling areas, at the approach to an intersection, a leveling area shall be provided having not greater than two percent rate at a distance of 60 feet, measured from the nearest right-of-way line of the intersecting street. 
e.  In a corner lot, there shall be no obstruction to vision between the height of three feet and ten feet above the average grade of each street within the triangular area formed by the intersection of two road rights-of-way and a line joining them at points 25 feet away from their intersection. 
(8)  Alleys and service drives. Alleys or service drives may be required on any lots used for multifamily, commercial, industrial, or mixed use developments. They shall not be provided in single-family residential areas except where the developer provides information to the planning commission of the need for a alley or service drive. 
(9)  Half streets. Half streets shall be prohibited, except where absolutely essential to the reasonable development of the planned project in conformity with other requirements in this chapter. Where the planning commission finds it practicable, it may require the dedication of the other half of the street when the adjoining property is developed. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. X, 10-6-1998) 
Secs. 46-83—46-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STREET DESIGN REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 46-101. - Street and road standards enumerated. 
Each new street or road shall be classified and designed for its entire length to meet the standards for the following street classes and land uses described as follows: 
(1)  Minimum right-of-way (in feet). 

 
(2)  Minimum width traveled route (in feet). 

 
WS (with shoulders - roll type curb) 
WC (with curbs - concrete vertical firm curbs) 
(3)  Maximum grade (percent). 

 
(4)  Minimum grade (percent). 

 
(5)  Minimum radius of curve (in feet). 

 
(6)  Minimum length of vertical curves. 
Local road: 100 feet.
