Collector road: 200 feet, but not less than 50 feet for each one percent in grade. 
Arterial road: 300 feet, but not less than 50 feet for each one percent in grade. 
(7)  Minimum length of tangents between reverse curves (in feet). 

 
(8)  Minimum sight distance (in feet). 

 
(9)  Minimum turnaround diameter (in feet). 

 
(10)  Required design speed (miles per hour). 

 
* Design speeds for these streets shall constitute minimum requirements. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XI, §§ 1101—1110, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-102. - Minimum length of cul-de-sac. 
The minimum length of a cul-de-sac shall be as follows: 
(1)  Permanent. A permanent cul-de-sac shall be six times the minimum lot width, serving no more than 12 families and not exceeding 800 feet in length. 
(2)  Temporary. A temporary cul-de-sac shall be 12 times the minimum lot width, serving no more than 24 families, and not exceeding 1,000 feet in length. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XI, § 1111, 10-6-1998) 
Secs. 46-103—46-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DESIGN STANDARDS FOR LOTS AND BLOCKS 

Sec. 46-121. - Design principles. 
Block design shall conform to sound design principles and the length, width and the shape shall be determined with due regard to: 
(1)  Zoning district requirements as to lot size. 
(2)  Topographic conditions. 
(3)  Need for safe, convenient access and traffic circulation. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XII, § 1201, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-122. - Design standards for blocks. 
The following standards shall apply to block design: 
(1)  Blocks shall have sufficient width to provide for two tiers of lots with appropriate depths. Exceptions to this prescribed block width shall be permitted in blocks adjacent to major streets, railroads, or waterways. 
(2)  The lengths, widths, and shapes of blocks shall be appropriate to the type of development contemplated and conducive to the existing street system, but block lengths for residential areas shall not exceed 2,200 feet or 12 times the minimum lot width required in the zoning district, nor be less than 400 feet in length. Wherever practicable, blocks along major arterials and collectors shall be at least 1,000 feet in length. 
(3)  In long blocks, the planning commission may require the reservation of an easement through the block to accommodate utilities, drainage facilities, or pedestrian traffic. Pedestrian ways, or crosswalks may be required by the planning commission through the center of blocks more than 800 feet long where deemed essential to provide circulation or access to schools, playgrounds, shopping centers, transportation or other community facilities. Blocks designed for commercial, industrial, or mixed uses shall be of such length and width as may be determined suitable by the planning commission for prospective use. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XII, § 1202, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-123. - Design standards for lots. 
The size, shape and orientation of lots shall be appropriate to the proposed subdivision or planned unit development and shall conform to the development standards for the applicable zoning district, unless appropriate modifications have been approved. Other standards shall include the following: 
(1)  No lot shall be subdivided by a city or county boundary. 
(2)  Every lot shall abut a street. 
(3)  Excessive lot depth in relation to width shall be avoided. A depth to width ratio of three to one shall normally be considered a maximum. 
(4)  Lots intended for purposes other than residential use shall be specifically designed for such purposes, and shall conform to the development standards for the applicable zoning district, unless appropriate modifications have been approved. 
(5)  Where parcels of land are subdivided into unusually large lots, such parcels shall be arranged to allow for the opening of future streets and logical further subdivision. 
(6)  Flag lots may be allowed on a limited basis where warranted by physical conditions of land form, existing lot pattern or unusual shape or size of parcels. Unless it can be demonstrated that the use of flag lots is a component of innovative site planning and design, the number of flag lots that may be permitted in any subdivision or planned unit development shall be limited in volume according to the following the scales of development, as follows: 
Subdivisions of two to 10.5 acres: one flag lot 
Subdivisions of 10.6 to 24.5 acres: two flag lots 
Subdivisions of 24.6 acres and above: three flag lots 
The narrow strip of land connecting the main portion of a flag lot shall not be less than 30 feet wide at any point so long as five-foot side lot utility easements are provided adjacent to the flag lot lines. The narrow strip of land shall also provide for practical vehicular and utility access. It shall not be used to help satisfy the minimum lot area requirement for any zoning district. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XII, § 1203, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-124. - Boundary markers required. 
(a)  The applicant shall place permanent boundary markers or monuments for reference in any planned unit development as required herein, and as approved by a registered land surveyor. 
(b)  Monuments shall be located on street right-of-way lines, at street intersections, angle points of curves and lot corners. They shall be spaced to be within sight distance of each other, the sight lines being wholly contained within the street limits. 
(c)  The external boundaries of a subdivision or planned unit development shall be monumented in the field by monuments of stone or concrete, not less than 30 inches in length, not less than four inches square or five inches in diameter, and marked on top with a cross, brass plug, iron rod, or other durable material securely embedded; or by iron rods or pipes at least 30 inches long and two inches in diameter. These monuments shall be placed not more than 1,400 feet apart in any straight line and at all corners, at the end of all curves, at the point where a curve changes its radius, at all angle points in any line, and at all angle points along the meander line, said points to be not less than 20 feet back from the bank of any river or stream, except that when such corners or points fall within a street, or proposed future street, the monuments shall be placed in the side line of the street. 
(d)  All internal boundaries and those corners and points not referred to in the preceding paragraph shall be monumented in the field by like monuments as described above. These monuments shall be placed at all block corners, at each end of all curves, at a point where a river changes its radius, and at all angle points at any line. 
(e)  The lines of lots that extend to rivers or streams shall be monumented in the field by iron pipes at least 30 inches long and seven-eighths of an inch in diameter or by round or square iron bars at least 30 inches long. These monuments shall be placed at the point of intersection of the river or stream lot line, with a meander line established not less than 20 feet back from the bank of the river or stream. 
(f)  All monuments shall be properly set in the ground and approved by a registered land surveyor prior to the time the planning commission recommends approval of the final plan. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XII, § 1204, 10-6-1998) 
Secs. 46-125—46-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - IMPROVEMENTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 46-161—46-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 46-181. - Generally. 
Prior to the approval of the final plat/plan, installation of street and utility improvements shall be made. The developer, at his own expense, shall be required to have installed street and utility improvements as required in this article. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XIII, § 1301, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-182. - Road surfacing and improvements. 
After all necessary sewer, water, and other underground utilities have been installed, the developer shall install curbs and gutters (where applicable) and shall surface or cause to be surfaced roadways to the widths described in this chapter. Said surfacing shall be of such character as is suitable for the expected traffic and in harmony with similar improvements in surrounding areas. Types of pavement shall be approved by the city road engineer or the state department of transportation. Adequate provision shall be made for culverts, drains, and bridges. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XIII, § 1302, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-183. - Shoulder, curb and gutter. 
Shoulders, curb, and gutters shall be installed on all applicable streets in a subdivision or planned unit development, but requirements shall vary according to street hierarchy and character of development (residential, non-residential, mixed-use) as indicated in the street design standards of this chapter. Curbing may also be required for: 
(1)  For stormwater management. 
(2)  Stabilizing the pavement edge. 
(3)  Delineating parking areas. 
(4)  Providing ten feet on either side of drainage inlets. 
(5)  Intersections. 
(6)  Corners. 
(7)  Tight curve radii. 
Where curbing is not required, edge delineation and stabilization shall be furnished to ensure safety and to prevent pavement separation. Where curbing is required, edge delineation shall be waived and shoulder and/or drainage swales used when it can be shown that shoulders are required by state law; soil or topography make the use of shoulders and/or drainage swales favorable; where it is in the best interest of the community to preserve its rural character by using shoulders and/or drainage swales instead of curbs. Flexibility regarding curb type shall be permitted as long as the curb type accommodates the system of drainage proposed. Shoulders shall measure four feet in width on each side for all applicable streets and shall be located within a right-of-way. Shoulders shall consist of stabilized turf or other materials as determined by the city road engineer or the state department of transportation. The width of swales shall be determined by site-specific conditions. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XIII, § 1303, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-184. - Stormwater management. 
The development should contain adequate stormwater management facilities to accommodate on-site the runoff that would be generated by a ten-year storm event. The planning commission may request assistance from the county soil conservation district, or the city engineer in evaluating the applicant's proposed measures to comply with this requirement. Any costs associated with this evaluation assistance shall be paid by the applicant. All drainage improvements shall tie into any available or natural drainageways along the adjoining public streets. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XIII, § 1304, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-185. - Street lighting. 
Installation of street lights may be required in accordance with design and specifications standards recommended by the local electric public utility system. However, the compatibility with the following guidelines shall be considered in developing a street lighting plan for a planned unit development: 
(1)  Lighting for safety should be provided at intersections, along walkways, at entryways, between buildings, and in parking areas. 
(2)  Spacing of street lights shall be equal to four times the height of the standard. 
(3)  The maximum height of the standard shall not exceed the maximum building height permitted, or 25 feet, whichever is less. 
(4)  The height and shielding of lighting standards shall provide proper lighting without hazard to drivers or nuisance to residents, and the design of lighting standards shall be of a type appropriate to the development and the community. 
(5)  Spotlights, if used, shall be placed on standards pointing toward the building and positioned as not to blind the residents, rather than on the buildings and directed outward which creates dark shadows adjacent to buildings. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XIII, § 1305, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-186. - Location of electrical utilities. 
It is desirable for all proposed wire or cable utilities to be located underground throughout any proposed planned unit development. In those instances in which it is not feasible to provide underground utilities, the applicant must demonstrate infeasibility to the satisfaction of the planning commission. The planning commission shall have the authority to waive such requirements, at its discretion. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XIII, § 1306, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-187. - Easements. 
Where easements are provided along rear lot lines for utilities (both private and public), such easements shall be at least ten feet wide. Proper coordination shall be established between the developer and appropriate utility companies for the establishment of utility easements on properties adjoining the planned unit development. Where topographical or other conditions make it impractical to place utilities on the rear lot lines, perpetual unobstructed easements at least ten feet in width shall be provided along side lot lines with satisfactory access to the road or rear lot lines. These easements shall, through deed covenants, be maintained clear of dense shrubbery, trees or fences. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XIII, § 1307, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-188. - Installation of water utilities. 
All subdivisions or planned unit developments must be connected to the public water system if they are within 1,000 feet of an available and appropriate system connection. Water mains for both domestic use and fire protection within the development shall be properly connected with the public water system. If public water is not available, an alternate water supply must be approved by the county health officer. The lines shall be constructed in such a manner as to serve adequately all lots shown on the subdivision plat/plan. The lines shall be installed in conformance with the technical standards as established by the city engineer. The city may incur the cost for any difference in the cost of the laying of oversized pipe and outfall systems which are needed in excess of the required water and sewer facilities needed to exclusively serve the new subdivision as determined by the planning commission and city council. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XIII, § 1308, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-189. - Installation of sewer utilities. 
A publicly connected sanitary sewer system shall be installed when a subdivision or planned unit development is within 1,000 feet of an available and appropriate system connection, or where the cost of installing such a system does not exceed 150 percent of the cost of installing septic tanks for all lots in the subdivision. Where lots cannot be economically connected with a sewerage system, they must contain adequate area for the installation of approved septic tank and disposal fields approved by the county health officer. All sewer facilities shall be installed in accordance with the standards of the state department of public health. The city may incur the cost for any difference in the cost of the laying of oversized pipe and outfall systems which are needed in excess of the required water and sewer facilities needed to exclusively serve the new subdivision as determined by the planning commission and city council. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XIII, § 1309, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-190. - Sidewalks required. 
The location of sidewalks shall be provided in each subdivision as follows: 
(1)  R-1A residential: none. 
(2)  R-1B residential: none. 
(3)  R-2 residential: only on one side of the street if subdivision or planned unit development has more than 20 dwelling units or has mixed uses. 
(4)  R-3 residential: only on one side of the street if subdivision or planned unit development has more than 20 dwelling units or has mixed uses. 
(5)  Other zoning districts: as required by the commission. 
Unless otherwise specified, all sidewalks shall be four inches thick with a minimum width of four feet. A 30-inch grass planting strip shall be provided between the back of the curb and the sidewalk. All sidewalks shall slope one-fourth of an inch to the foot toward the curb. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XIII, § 1310, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-191. - Street signs required. 
(a)  All new or existing roads, public or private, which are included in a subdivision shall be furnished and installed with street name signs. All necessary traffic signs (slow, stop, caution, school bus stop, etc.) will be furnished and installed at proper locations. Materials for signs shall be approved by the planning commission, and all expenses incurred will be borne by the developer at no cost to the city. 
(b)  All streets shall be designated by name on a street sign post approved by the planning commission with such post having a set of nameplates/planes of an approved material one above the other with a clearance of seven feet. The post shall be located to be visible for both pedestrian and vehicular traffic. At cross-street intersections in all zoning districts other than an R-1A, R-1B, or agricultural district, two street sign posts shall be located diagonally across the intersection from each other. Only one street sign post shall be required at T-street intersections. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XIII, § 1311, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-192. - Water supply requirements for fire suppression. 
The city fire chief shall compute the minimum water supply needed for any degree of fire control for proposed developments, and will see that adequate fire flows are available to meet the needs indicated. In areas supported by public or community water systems, fire hydrants shall be distributed throughout any development with a distance of no less than 1,000 feet of distance between each hydrant. Fire protection shall be furnished for any developments connected to the public water supply system, and minimum fire flows shall be computed based on standards promulgated by the city fire chief. For those proposed developments which will not have immediate access to the public water supply system, such standards and computations should be based on the National Fire Protection Association Standards on Water Supply for Suburban and Rural Fire Fighting (ANSI/NFPA No. 1231; 07/1989). 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XIII, § 1312, 10-6-1998) 
Secs. 46-193—46-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DEVELOPMENT IMPROVEMENT RESPONSIBILITIES AND ASSURANCES 

Sec. 46-221. - Purpose of division. 
Improvement responsibilities and assurances shall be provided to ensure the proper installation and maintenance of required improvements. The nature and duration of any arrangement requiring the documentation of improvement responsibilities and assurances shall be structured to achieve this goal without adding unnecessary costs to the developer. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XIV, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-222. - Application. 
Before recording final subdivision plat/plans, and as a condition of final plat/plan approval, the planning commission may approve and shall accept in accordance with the standards adopted by the chapter the following assurances: 
(1)  The furnishing of a performance assurance in an amount not to exceed 120 percent of the estimated or projected cost of installation for improvements. 
(2)  For a planned unit developments of more than 20 lots or ten acres, provisions for a maintenance assurance shall be made for a period not to exceed two years after the final acceptance of the improvement, in an amount not to exceed 25 percent of the cost of the improvement. In the event that other governmental agencies or public utilities will automatically own the utilities to be installed, or the improvements are covered by a performance or maintenance assurance to another governmental agency, no performance or maintenance assurance shall be required by the planning commission. 
(3)  The time allowed for the installation of the improvements for which the performance assurance has been provided may be extended by the building official or city manager, upon the recommendation of applicable department or agency heads, provided that the applicant has demonstrated a good faith effort to complete the improvements in accordance with the approved construction schedule. 
(4)  Upon substantial completion of all required improvements, the developer may notify the planning commission, on behalf of the building official or city manager, in writing that such substantial completion has taken place. The building official or city manager, or his designated agent, may inspect all improvements to assure compliance with applicable standards. The building official or city manager shall prepare and file a report on the status of the affected improvements. If approved, the building official or city manager may notify the development party in writing that the specified improvements satisfy all applicable requirements. If only partially approved, or disapproved, the building official or city manager shall notify the developer in writing regarding any deficiencies concerning specified improvements, and shall indicate any corrective action to be taken. Where partial approval is granted, the developer shall be released from all liability except for that portion of improvements not yet approved. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XIV, § 1401, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 46-223. - Performance and maintenance mechanisms. 
Performance and maintenance assurances may be provided by a variety of means including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Security bond. The applicant may obtain a security bond from a surety bonding company authorized to do business in the state. 
(2)  Letter of credit. The applicant may provide an irrevocable letter of credit from a bank or other reputable institution. 
(3)  Escrow account. The applicant shall deposit cash or other instruments readily convertible into cash at face value, either with the city or in a bank escrow account. 
(4)  Property. The applicant may provide as an assurance land or other property. 
(5)  Development improvement agreement. An applicant may provide as an assurance an improvement agreement between the applicant, lender and the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 99-05B, art. XIV, § 1402, 10-6-1998) 
Chapter 50 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness saved from repeal, § 1-6(2); any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes for such improvements saved from repeal, § 1-6(9); any ordinance levying or imposing taxes not included in this Code saved from repeal, § 1-6(14). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 50-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Administrative fee means the component of the occupation tax which approximates the reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax. 
Dominant line means the type of business within a multiple line business, which is the major and principal source of such business at a single location. Businesses occupying space at the same location as a multiple-line business under a separate name or another business entity shall not be considered a part of the multiple line business. 
Employee means an individual whose work is performed under the direction and supervision of the employer and whose employer withholds FICA, federal income tax, or state income tax from such person's compensation or whose employer issues to such persons for purposes of documenting compensation a form IRS W-2, but not a form IRS 1099; and, is any individual who, for compensation, exerts substantial effort within the state for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients. 
Location or office means a fixed place located within the city from which a person conducts business, but shall not include a temporary or construction work site located in the city for less than six months for the purpose of serving a single customer or project which serves a single customer or project or a vehicle used for sales or delivery by a business or practitioner of a profession or occupation which has a location or office. 
Occupation tax means a tax levied for revenue purposes on persons, partnerships, corporations or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession or business for revenue raising purposes in the city. 
Occupation tax certificate means a document issued by the city acknowledging payment of the occupation tax and administrative fee. 
Person means sole proprietors, corporations, partnerships, for-profit, or any other form of business organization, but specifically excludes all nonprofit organizations. 
Practitioners of professions and occupations means as described in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5, but does not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business if such business pays an occupation tax. 
Regulatory fee means a fee, whether designated as license fees, permit fees or another name, which are required by the local government as an exercise of its police power and as a part of or an aid to the regulation of an occupation, profession or business. Such fee shall approximate the cost of regulatory activity by the city. The regulatory fee cannot include an administrative fee. Development impact fees as defined by O.C.G.A. § 36-71-2 or other costs or conditions of zoning or land development are not regulatory fees. 
Regulatory fee certificate means a document issued by the city acknowledging payment of a regulatory fee. 
(Ord. No. 99-04B, § 5-101, 10-6-1998) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 50-2. - Administrative fee. 
A non-prorated, non-refundable administrative fee on file in the clerk's office is required on all occupation tax accounts for the initial registration, annual renewal or reopening of such accounts. 
(Ord. No. 99-04B, § 5-102, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 50-3. - Regulatory fee. 
(a)  Businesses and persons engaging in the occupations or businesses set forth in Appendix A must pay a non-refundable regulatory fee in accordance with the rate set forth in Appendix A to Ordinance No. 99-04B. The regulatory fee is an exercise of the police power of the city. The regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee unless the business regulated is subject to an occupational tax as determined in this chapter. 
(b)  If a business or individual initially engages in an activity regulated by the city on or after April 1 in any year, the regulatory fee for the remaining portion of the year shall be reduced 25 percent of the regulatory fee for each successive three month period thereafter, with a minimum proration of 25 percent of the annual fee for all certificates issued on or after October 1 in any year. 
(c)  Every business, individual and location subject to payment of a regulatory fee levied by this chapter shall display a current regulatory fee certificate in a conspicuous place at the location for which such certificate was issued. If the taxpayer does not have a permanent location within the city, the regulatory fee certificate or an unaltered duplicate of such certificate shall be shown on request. 
(Ord. No. 99-04B, § 5-103, 10-6-1998) 
Editor's note— Appendix A to Ordinance No. 99-04B is not printed herein but is on file in the clerk's office. 
Sec. 50-4. - Occupation tax levied; limitations. 
An occupation tax based upon number of employees in the state is levied upon businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with one or more locations or offices within the corporate limits of the city and, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, upon out-of-state businesses with no location or office in the city but with employees or agents engaging in substantial efforts to solicit business or serve customers or clients in the state. The occupation tax shall be determined according to the number of employees of the business or practitioner as computed on a full-time position basis or full-time equivalent basis, provided that for the purposes of this computation, any employee who works 40 hours or more weekly shall be considered a full-time employee and that the average weekly hours of employees who work less than 40 hours weekly shall be added and such sum shall be divided by 40 to produce full-time position equivalents. In addition to the employee tax method, a flat fee of $15.00 shall be applied uniformly to persons, businesses and practitioners whose location for occupation tax purposes is within the city limits. The occupation tax and flat fee shall be computed in accordance with the schedule on file in the clerk's office. 
(1)  The city shall not require the payment of more than one occupation tax for each location of a business or practitioner. 
(2)  A business or practitioner which is subject to an occupation tax by another local government and claiming an exemption from or limitation to the occupation tax imposed by this section shall submit documentation as to current payment of the occupation tax to the other local government and the basis of such tax. 
a.  If a business or practitioner with no location or office in the state provides to the city proof of payment of a local business or occupation tax in another state which purports to tax the business's or practitioner's sales or services in this state, then the business or practitioner shall be exempt from this occupation tax. 
b.  A business or practitioner with no location or office in this state shall only be required to pay occupation tax to the local government in this state where the largest dollar volume of business is done or service is performed by such business or practitioner. This limitation shall only apply when the business or practitioner has provided to the city satisfactory proof of the applicability of this subsection. 
c.  A business or practitioner which has locations in this state subject to occupation tax by more than one local government in the state shall only be subject to occupation tax by the city for the number of employees who are employed within the corporate limits of the city. This limitation shall only apply when the business or practitioner has provided to the city satisfactory proof of current payment of the occupation tax of the other local governments. 
d.  If an employee works for the same business or practitioner in more than one municipal corporation or county and the business or practitioner submits proof of this, the employee shall be counted as an employee in the city only if the city is the jurisdiction where such employee works for the longest period of time within the calendar year. 
(3)  If a business or practitioner commences business in the city on or after April in any year, the occupation tax and flat fee for the remaining portion of the year shall be reduced 25 percent for each successive three-month period thereafter, with a minimum proration of 25 percent of the annual fee for all certificates issued on or after October 1 in any year. The administrative fee shall not be reduced. 
(4)  If a business or practitioner does not know how many employees which are the basis of this occupation tax will be employed by the business or practitioner during the current calendar year, then the business or practitioner shall file a return estimating the number of employees which are the basis of this occupation tax. If such estimate is not accurate, then no later than December 31 the business or practitioner shall file an amended return indicating the actual number of employees during the previous calendar year. Any overpayment of the occupation tax may be credited to the business or practitioner's account for future tax liability, offset against other amounts due and owing to the city for any reason or paid to the business or practitioner at the discretion of the clerk. 
(5)  Real estate brokers shall be subject to occupation tax pursuant to this chapter only if they maintain a principal or branch office in the city. 
(6)  Depository institutions located within the city limits shall pay a business license tax at a rate not to exceed 0.25 percent of gross receipts as defined and allocated according to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. 
(7)  Newly established businesses, occupations or practitioners within the corporate limits may not use or cause to be transferred an existing occupational tax certificate. Such newly established businesses, occupations or practitioners shall be liable for payment of an occupational tax subject to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 99-04B, § 5-104, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 50-5. - Occupation tax certificate. 
Every business, practitioner and location subject to payment of the occupation tax levied by this chapter shall display a current occupation tax certificate in a conspicuous place at the location for which such certificate was issued. If the taxpayer does not have a permanent location within the city, the occupation tax certificate shall be shown to any designated city official upon request. 
(Ord. No. 99-04B, § 5-105, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 50-6. - Practitioners of professions and occupations. 
Practitioners of professions and occupations as defined in this chapter shall pay the occupation tax as set forth in section 50-4 or shall pay an occupation tax of $250.00 per practitioner. On the tax return for 1995 or such later time as the practitioner first commences business in the city, the practitioner shall elect a method of taxation. Such election shall be changed for subsequent calendar years only by a written request filed by the practitioner on or before November 1 prior to the year in which the election is to be changed. 
(Ord. No. 99-04B, § 5-106, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 50-7. - Exemptions. 
(a)  No occupation tax shall be levied on the following: 
(1)  Any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the United States, the state, a municipality or county of the state, or instrumentality of the United States, the state, or a municipality or county of the state; 
(2)  Those businesses regulated by the state public service commission; 
(3)  Those electrical service businesses organized under O.C.G.A. § 46-3-1 et seq.; 
(4)  Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including any agribusiness; 
(5)  Non-profit, agricultural product cooperative marketing associations pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105; 
(6)  Motor common carriers pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15; 
(7)  Persons purchasing guano, meats, meal, flour, bran, cottonseed, or cottonseed meal or hulls in carload lots for distribution among the purchasers for use and not sale pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355; 
(8)  Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356 for persons selling or introducing into the city agricultural products or livestock, including animal products, raised in this state when the sale and introduction are made by the producer of the product and the sale is made within 90 days of the introduction of the product into the city; 
(9)  Depository institutions pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93; 
(10)  Any non-profit organization or facilities operated by a charitable trust governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-55. 
(b)  The exemptions and limitations contained in this section shall not be construed to repeal or otherwise affect in any way any franchise fees, business taxes or other fees or taxes otherwise allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. 99-04B, § 5-107, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 50-8. - Evidence of state registration when required. 
Each person who is licensed under O.C.G.A. § 43-1-1 et seq. by the examining boards of the secretary of state's office shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensure before any city occupation tax certificate or regulatory fee certificate may be issued. 
(Ord. No. 99-04B, § 5-108, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 50-9. - Evidence of qualification required if applicable. 
(a)  Any business required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of an occupation tax certificate or a regulatory fee certificate, show evidence of such qualification. 
(b)  Any business required to submit an annual application for continuance of the business shall do so before the registration is issued. 
(Ord. No. 99-04B, § 5-109, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 50-10. - Filing returns; other information required or requested. 
(a)  On or before November 1 of each year, an individual, business or practitioner subject to this occupation tax shall file with the city clerk on a form approved by and available from the city a signed return attesting to the number of employees of such business or practitioner during the calendar year. 
(b)  Persons, businesses and practitioners doing business in the city shall submit to the clerk or make available within 30 days such information as may be required or requested by the city to determine the applicability and amount of the occupation tax or regulatory fee or to facilitate levying or collection of the occupation tax and/or regulatory fees. 
(c)  The business registration of each business operated in the city's jurisdiction shall identify the line of business that the business conducts. No business shall conduct any line of business without first having that line of business registered with the city and that line of business being noted by the city on the business registration form which is to be displayed by the business owner. 
(Ord. No. 99-04B, § 5-110, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 50-11. - Confidentiality. 
Information provided by a business or practitioner to the city for the purpose of determining the applicability and amount of the occupation tax or levying or collecting the occupation tax is confidential and exempt from disclosure under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-15. Such information may be provided to the governing authority of another local government for occupation tax purposes or pursuant to court order or for the purpose of collecting occupation tax or prosecution for failure or refusal to pay occupation tax. 
(Ord. No. 99-04B, § 5-111, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 50-12. - Date due; penalty. 
(a)  Any occupation tax or regulatory fee due pursuant to this chapter shall be due and payable annually on January 1. In the event that any person commences business or initially engages in a regulated activity in the city after January 1 in any year, the tax and/or fee shall be due and payable on the date of the commencement of the business or regulated activity. 
(b)  Any person, business or practitioner subject to any occupation tax or regulatory fee imposed by this chapter which is unpaid for 90 days after the date on which payment was required is subject to a penalty of ten percent of the tax, and an additional 1.5 percent will be imposed for each additional month of delinquency thereof. 
(Ord. No. 99-04B, § 5-112, 10-6-1998) 
Sec. 50-13. - Enforcement; violations. 
(a)  It is the duty of the clerk to administer and enforce the provisions of this article, to perform all functions necessary to administer and enforce this article and to summon violators of this article to appear before the municipal court. The clerk may issue executions against persons, businesses and practitioners for taxes and fees which are due and owing. 
(b)  The clerk shall issue executions against persons, businesses and practitioners for taxes and fees which are due and owing. Such executions shall bear interest at the rate authorized by O.C.G.A. § 48-2-40 or, if such statute should be repealed, one percent per month. The lien shall cover the property of the individual, business or practitioner liable for payment of the delinquent occupation tax or regulatory fee and become fixed as of the date and time the occupation tax or regulatory fee become delinquent. The execution shall be levied by clerk upon property of the delinquent tax or fee payer located in the city and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of the execution, including penalty, interest and costs. All other proceedings in relation thereto shall be as provided by the Code, Charter and the laws of the state. The defendants at execution shall have the rights of defense, by affidavit of illegality of the tax or otherwise as provided by the Charter and the laws of the state in regard to tax executions. 
(c)  When a nulla bona entry has been entered upon an execution, the person against whom the entry is made shall not be allowed or entitled to have or collect any fees or charge whatever for services rendered after the entry of the nulla bona. If, at any time after the nulla bona entry has been made, the person against whom the execution issues pays the tax in full, together with all interest and costs accrued on the tax, the person may collect any fees and charges due to such person as if such person had never defaulted in the payment of the tax. 
(d)  Persons, businesses and practitioners who fail or refuse to pay any occupation tax or regulatory fee charged pursuant to this chapter shall be subject to a $25.00 fine with each day of non-compliance considered as a separate offense. 
(e)  Persons, businesses and practitioners who fail or refuse to make a timely or truthful tax return or make available truthful and accurate information the city requests or requires for determining applicability or amount of occupation tax or regulatory fee, or for levying or collecting such occupation tax or regulatory fee shall be subject to either a fine as prescribed herein, and/or the suspension of the right to conduct business. 
(f)  Persons, businesses or practitioners subject to the occupation tax or regulatory fees imposed by this chapter shall be required to file for and pay such tax or fee. For failure to do so, any officers or agents soliciting for or obtaining such business shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons, businesses or practitioners who fail to obtain make a return for or pay the applicable occupation tax or regulatory fee. 
(g)  Persons, businesses or practitioners subject to the occupation tax or regulatory fees imposed by this chapter who fail to comply with this chapter shall be subject to the penalties provided herein. In the case of those practitioners where the city cannot suspend the right of the practitioner to conduct business, the imposition of civil penalties shall be permitted and pursued by the city in the case of a delinquent occupational tax, as prescribed in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 99-04B, § 5-113, 10-6-1998) 
Secs. 50-14—50-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - INSURER LICENSE FEES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 14-45, adopted July, 8 2014, amended Art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. II, §§ 50-41—50-46, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from an ordinance adopted Jan. 8, 1991, §§ 1—6. 

Sec. 50-41. - Insurers license fees. 
There is hereby levied for the year 2015 and for each year thereafter an annual license fee upon each insurer doing business within the City of Glennville, Georgia in the amount of $50.00. For each separate business location in excess of one not covered by section 50-42, which is operating on behalf of such insurers within the City of Glennville, Georgia, there is hereby levied a license fee in the amount of $50.00. For the purposes of this article, the term "insurer" means a company which is authorized to transact business in any of the classes of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5. 
(Res. No. 14-45, 7-8-2014) 
Sec. 50-42. - License fees for insurers insuring certain risks at additional business locations. 
For each separate business location, not otherwise subject to a license fee hereunder, operated and maintained by a business organization which is engaged in the business of lending money or transacting sales involving term financing and in connection with such loans or sales offers, solicits or takes application for insurance through a licensed agent of an insurer for insurance said insurer shall pay an additional license fee of $17.50 per location for the year 2015 and for each year thereafter. 
(Res. No. 14-45, 7-8-2014) 
Sec. 50-43. - Gross premiums tax imposed on life insurers. 
There is hereby levied for the year 2015 and for each year thereafter an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer writing life, accident and sickness insurance within the State of Georgia in an amount equal to one percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1. Gross direct premiums as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fee imposed by section 50-41. 
(Res. No. 14-45, 7-8-2014) 
Sec. 50-44. - Gross premiums tax, all other insurers. 
There is hereby levied for the year 2015 and for each year thereafter an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer, other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated in subsection 1 of O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5, doing business within the State of Georgia in an amount equal to two and one-half percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A § 33-8-8-2. Gross direct premiums as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 50-41. 
(Res. No. 14-45, 7-8-2014) 
Sec. 50-45. - Due date for license fees. 
License fee imposed in sections 50-41 and 50-42 shall be due and payable on the first day of 2015 and on the first date of each subsequent year. 
(Res. No. 14-45, 7-8-2014) 
Sec. 50-46. - Administrative provisions. 
The city clerk is hereby directed to forward a duly certified copy of the ordinance from which this article derives to the Insurance Commissioner of the State of Georgia within 45 days of its enactment. 
(Res. No. 14-45, 7-8-2014) 
Sec. 50-47. - Effective date. 
This article shall become effective January 1, 2015. 
(Res. No. 14-45, 7-8-2014) 
Secs. 50-48—50-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AUCTIONS, THRIFT STORES AND CONSIGNMENT STORES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Res. No. 15-12A, adopted Mar. 11, 2015, amended Art. III in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. III, §§ 50-81—50-86, pertained to auctions, and derived from Code 1982, § 5-210(1)—(6). 
State Law reference— Auctions generally, O.C.G.A. § 43-6-1 et seq. 

Sec. 50-81. - Definitions. 
[The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
Business means any business that accepts items for auction, sale or consignment basis. 
Minor means any person younger than 18. 
Owner means any business owner to include his/her employees that accepts items for auction. sale or consignment basis on behalf of the business. 
Property owner/seller means person offering the property for sale or consignment. 
Report means written records used by business detailing items purchased or consigned, i.e., consignment sheets, receipt, etc., that includes signature of property owner/consignor. 
(Res. No. 15-12A, 3-11-2015) 
Sec. 50-82. - License required. 
Each person who desires to conduct an auction, thrift store or consignment within this city shall be required to obtain a license therefore from the city clerk in the manner specified in this article. 
(Res. No. 15-12A, 3-11-2015) 
Sec. 50-83. - Fee established. 
The business license fee for each auction licensed under this article shall be $150.00. 
(Res. No. 15-12A, 3-11-2015) 
Sec. 50-84. - License application. 
(a)  Application for a license under this article shall contain the following additional information: 
(1)  A statement setting forth when, where, and for how long the business sale will be conducted; 
(2)  A certified copy of the state auctioneer's license of the person, if applicable, who is to conduct the auction; and 
(3)  A full and true inventory of all the articles to be sold at the auction sale, together with an affidavit that all information contained in the application is true and that the inventory contains a true listing of all the articles to be sold at said auction, if applicable. 
(b)  No auction sale shall be held except as set forth in the application and affidavit, and no other articles shall be sold except those included in the sworn inventory unless a new affidavit shall be filed listing the additional goods to be sold. No other person shall be allowed to conduct the auction sale except such person listed in the affidavit unless a new affidavit is filed setting forth such other person who may be employed to conduct such auction and cry off such goods, if applicable. 
(Res. No. 15-12A, 3-11-2015) 
Sec. 50-85. - Bond. 
Every owner for a license under this article shall file with the city clerk a surety bond running to the city with surety acceptable to and approved by the city clerk, conditioned that the said owner, if issued a license hereunder, will comply fully with all of the provisions of the ordinances of this city and the statutes regulating and concerning auctions, auctioneers. Thrift stores or consignment stores will render true and strict accounts of all his sales to any person employing him to make the same, will not practice any fraud or deceit upon bidders or purchasers of property from him at any auction sale or suffer or permit any person in his employ to practice any such fraud or deceit, and will pay all damages which may be sustained by any person by reason of any fraud, deceit, negligence or other wrongful act on the part of the licensee, his agent or employees in the conduct of any auction or in the exercise of the calling of auctioneer. A liability insurance policy issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in this state which conforms to the above requirements may be permitted by the clerk in his discretion in lieu of a bond. 
(Res. No. 15-12A, 3-11-2015) 
Sec. 50-86. - Cappers, boosters, or by-bidders. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to act or to employ another in any auction sale as a by-bidder or what is sometimes known as a "capper" or "booster," or to make or to accept any false or misleading bid, or to pretend to buy or sell any article sold or offered for sale at such business. 
(Res. No. 15-12A, 3-11-2015) 
Sec. 50-87. - Maintenance of records required; contents; terms. 
(a)  Every owner shall maintain records which shall contain in legible English the following information: 
(1)  For purchases or consignments received from individuals for all items on sequenced numbered reports as specified under Secretary of States' Rules and Regulations for the State of Georgia for Georgia Auctioneers Commission, Conduct of Auctions, 55-5-.01 — Responsibilities of the Auctioneer as well as in this Code: 
a.  An executed contract, which shall include: 
i.  The name(s) and address(es), telephone number(s), and signature(s) of the seller(s) of the property offered; 
ii.  The name(s) and address(es), telephone number(s), and signature(s) of the auctioneer (owner) in charge of the sale; 
iii.  Date of execution; 
iv.  Proposed date of and place that the auction is to be held; 
v.  Terms of compensation; 
vi.  Date of proposed settlement. 
b.  A closing statement which shall include: 
i.  The name(s) and address(es) of the seller(s) of the property offered; 
ii.  The price at which the property sold; 
iii.  The date and place of said auction; 
iv.  The date the proceeds were delivered to said owner; 
v.  Signature(s) of the seller(s); and 
vi.  List of items sold. 
c.  Photocopy of driver's license or other form of identification of seller. 
(b)  Reports shall be submitted to the Glennville Police Department via hand-delivery, fax or email no less than weekly on or before 5:00 p.m. of Wednesday of each week. 
(c)  Items purchased or consigned must be identified individually by sequenced number of report or grouped together collectively with identifiable sequenced number attached. 
(d)  The records required by this Code section shall be maintained for a period of not less than three years. 
(e)  The records required by this Code section shall be open to the inspection of any duly authorized law enforcement officer during the ordinary hours of business. 
(Res. No. 15-12A, 3-11-2015) 
Sec. 50-88. - Identification required. 
(a)  Each owner shall required that any person selling or placing articles on consignment shall display evidence of acceptable identification such as a duly issued state driver's license or identification and the owner shall photocopy the driver's license or other such evidence of identification on the required form for the transaction. 
(b)  The owner will have the affirmative duty to compare all pictures, physical descriptions and signatures on the identification presented and shall not transact any business with a person who in the owner's opinion appears to be presenting false or altered identification. If the identification presented is not a State of Georgia issued identification, the owner will have the affirmative duty of providing the listed address from the identification as well as current Georgia address on the transaction paperwork. The owner is required to check the customer's identification for each transaction. If the records show identification other than that presented. this must be corrected during the current transaction. 
(Res. No. 15-12A, 3-11-2015) 
Sec. 50-89. - Holding period of items. 
Every owner will cause all item s purchased or consigned to be held from immediate sale or auction until items are either released by appointed law enforcement officer of the City of Glennville or waiting period not to exceed ten calendar days has expired. The items will remain onsite until either released by police officer or ten calendar days has expired. 
(Res. No. 15-12A, 3-11-2015) 
Sec. 50-90. - Police holds on materials purchased or consigned. 
Whenever a law enforcement officer shall have probable cause to suspect any property listed in the report is stolen property or constitutes evidence of a crime or that any individual has committed a crime or that possession of the property is criminal, the owner shall be notified in writing not to sell, destroy, alter or remove the property from the physical boundaries of the business facility. These hold notices will be provided by law enforcement in writing and will specifically identify the items corresponding to the sequenced report number to be held. 
(Res. No. 15-12A, 3-11-2015) 
Sec. 50-91. - Exclusions. 
Items that shall be excluded from hold shall include the following: 
(1)  Items purchased from storage units and/or estate sales. However, documentation of purchase or consignment shall be provided. 
(2)  Clothing. 
(3)  Household goods to include pots, pans, flatware, sheets, pillows, trinkets, decorations, etc. 
(Res. No. 15-12A, 3-11-2015) 
Sec. 50-92. - Minors. 
No owner shall purchase or accept consignment for any property from a minor. 
(Res. No. 15-12A, 3-11-2015) 
Sec. 50-93. - Stolen goods. 
It shall be the duty of every owner to report to the police any article placed with him/her that he/she shall have reason to believe the item(s) was stolen or lost and found by that person attempting to place the item for auction. 
(Res. No. 15-12A, 3-11-2015) 
Sec. 50-94. - Penalties for violation. 
Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 per violation or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. In addition to such fine or imprisonment, any person failing to comply with any provision of this article, or other laws, ordinances, or regulation as may be passed by the city in regulating the business, shall be grounds for immediate suspension or revocation of the city business license issued hereunder. 
(Res. No. 15-12A, 3-11-2015) 
Sec. 50-95. - Exemptions. 
Nothing in this article shall be held to apply to auction sales conducted by trustees or referees in bankruptcy, executors, administrators, receivers or other public officers acting under judicial process, nor to the sale of real property at business. 
(Res. No. 15-12A, 3-11-2015) 
Secs. 50-96—50-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BILLIARDS OR POOL ROOMS 

Sec. 50-121. - License requirement. 
(a)  Each person keeping, operating or maintaining a billiard table, pool table or any other table of like character within the corporate limits of the city for use by the public shall be required to obtain a license from the city clerk in the manner specified in this article. Said license shall be classified as a "premises where alcoholic beverages will be sold, consumed used or where patrons have consumed alcoholic beverages" or a "premises where sale of alcoholic beverages, the use thereof, consumption or possession is prohibited." 
(b)  As a prerequisite to the issuance of the license, the applicant shall visit the Tattnall County Sheriff Department for fingerprinting. The sheriff department will process the fingerprints through Georgia Crime Information Center (GCIC) for determination of any past criminal activity. The sheriff department will provide the city results of investigation. 
(c)  The chief of police will review the Georgia Crime Information Center's background report of the applicant and provide recommendations to the mayor and council. 
(d)  After its final investigation, the mayor and city council shall grant or deny the license applied for. 
(Ord. of 3-3-1992, § 1; Res. No. 10-41, 7-13-2010; Res. No. 11-01, 8-3-2010) 
Sec. 50-122. - Fees established. 
The annual business license fee for each operator of a billiard or pool room in the city shall be an amount on file in the clerk's office for the first table, and an amount on file in the clerk's office for each additional table. 
(Ord. of 3-3-1992, § 2) 
Sec. 50-123. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  Premises where alcoholic beverages are sold, consumed, used or where patrons have consumed alcoholic beverages. It shall be unlawful for the owner, operator or manager of any billiard or pool room in the city to permit such establishment to be open for business between the hours of 12:00 midnight through 6:00 a.m., Monday through Saturday, and from 12:00 midnight Saturday through 6:00 a.m. Monday. 
(b)  Premises where sale of alcoholic beverages, the use thereof, consumption or possession is prohibited. It shall be unlawful for the owner, operator or manager of any billiard or pool room in the city to permit such establishment to be open for business between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m., Monday through Thursday, between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 8:00 a.m., Friday through Saturday, and between the hours of 12:00 midnight Saturday through 8:00 a.m. Monday. Should the owner of any establishment allow patrons to consume, use or possess alcoholic beverages on said premises he shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine up to $500.00 or six months in jail. This subsection shall likewise apply to controlled substances and shall also include patrons who have consumed alcohol or controlled substances away from said premises but while upon said premises have alcohol or controlled substances within their system. It being the intent of this licensing classification to provide recreation facilities for the youth of the city and it is declared by this article to be detrimental to their health and welfare to be in business establishments where patrons are either consuming, using or in possession of alcoholic beverages or controlled substances or have the same within their system. 
(Ord. of 3-3-1992, § 3) 
Sec. 50-124. - Minors. 
It shall be unlawful for any person having charge or control of any pool room or billiard room open to the public for which alcoholic beverages are sold, consumed, used or where patrons have consumed alcoholic beverages to permit into such room any individual under the age of 21 years, whether for the purpose of playing billiards or pool or not. 
(Ord. of 3-3-1992, § 4) 
Sec. 50-125. - Clear view of premises required. 
The owner, operator or manager of any billiard or pool room in the city shall not permit to be used on such premises any screens, shades, partitions or other devices of like character which shall have the effect of obstructing the view through the windows or doors of the place where the billiard or pool tables are kept. 
(Ord. of 3-3-1992, § 5) 
Sec. 50-126. - Doors. 
The doors of a billiard or pool room licensed under this article shall be kept unlocked whenever the tables are in use, or when any person other than the proprietor or his agent is present in such place. 
(Ord. of 3-3-1992, § 6) 
Sec. 50-127. - Gambling. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner, operator or manager of any billiard or pool room open for public use to allow gambling of any kind to occur upon such premises. 
(Ord. of 3-3-1992, § 7) 
Secs. 50-128—50-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CIRCUSES, CARNIVALS AND PUBLIC EXHIBITIONS 

Sec. 50-161. - License required. 
No person, firm, or corporation shall conduct or operate a circus, carnival or public exhibition, as such terms are defined in section 50-162, without having first obtained a license from the city clerk in the manner specified in this article. 
(Code 1982, § 5-211(1)) 
Sec. 50-162. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Carnival means amusement activities, rides, merry-go-rounds, booths for the conduct of games of skill, food dispensing facilities and sideshows. 
Public exhibition means circuses, menageries, sideshows and other similar itinerant amusement enterprises which are open to the public and for admission to which a fee is charged. 
(Code 1982, § 5-211(2)) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 50-163. - Fees established. 
The daily application fee imposed on each circus, carnival, or public exhibition operating within the city limits shall be as follows: 
For circuses\$50.00 
For carnivals\50.00 
For sideshows and concessions\15.00 
For rides\15.00 
For other public exhibitions\15.00 
(Code 1982, § 5-211(3)) 
Sec. 50-164. - Conditions of issuance. 
No license under this article shall be issued until the following conditions have been met: 
(1)  The operator and sponsor of the circus, carnival, or public exhibition have each assumed full responsibility for maintaining order and for keeping the site clean and free of trash, paper and other debris, and have placed trash containers in adequate number and in convenient locations for the use of the public. 
(2)  All rides have been inspected for mechanical, structural, electrical, and other hazards by the appropriate officers and employees of the city, and adequate safeguards have been placed to protect both operators and the general public from inadvertently coming into contact with moving parts, belts, motor gears, electrical switches and other possible or potential hazards. 
(3)  The applicant has placed on file with the city clerk a certificate or certificates of insurance indicating that there is in effect public liability insurance covering any damages arising out of the use and operation of any and all devices and facilities operated in connection with such carnival or exhibition. Such insurance shall be in the minimum amount of $100,000.00 for each person, and $300,000.00 for each accident. 
(Code 1982, § 5-211(4)) 
Sec. 50-165. - Inspections. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police and the fire chief to see that proper inspections and patrols are made of the premises used for the activities licensed herein. 
(Code 1982, § 5-211(5)) 
Secs. 50-166—50-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTORS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 10. 

Sec. 50-201. - Plumbers. 
No master, contracting, or journeyman plumber, as such terms are defined in O.C.G.A. § 43-14-2 shall be permitted to engage in any plumbing business in this city unless such person shall hold a valid certificate of qualification issued to him by the division of master plumbers and journeyman plumbers. 
(Code 1982, § 5-203(1)) 
Sec. 50-202. - Electrical contractors. 
No electrical contractor, as such term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 43-14-2 shall be permitted to engage in any electrical contracting business in this city unless such person shall hold a valid license issued to him by the division of electrical contractors. 
(Code 1982, § 5-203(2)) 
Sec. 50-203. - Conditioned air contractors. 
No conditioned air contractor, as such term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 43-14-2, shall be permitted to engage in any warm air contracting business in this city unless such person shall hold a valid certificate of qualification issued to him by the division of conditioned air contractors or by the county in which this city is located. 
(Code 1982, § 5-203(3)) 
Sec. 50-204. - General contractors. 
All general contractors who contract with this city for any public work exceeding $1,000.00 in amount shall be required to obtain a performance and payment bond in the amount and manner specified by law. 
(Code 1982, § 5-203(4)) 
Secs. 50-205—50-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - GOING-OUT-OF-BUSINESS SALES AND FIRE SALES 

Sec. 50-241. - License required. 
Any person selling or offering to sell any goods within this city at a sale to be advertised or held out by any means to be a going-out-of-business sale, or removal of business sale, or a fire and other altered stock sale, as such terms are defined in this section, shall be required to obtain a license from the city clerk in the manner specified in this article. 
(Code 1982, § 5-206(1)) 
Sec. 50-242. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Fire and other altered goods sale means a sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that the sale will offer goods damaged or altered by fire, smoke, water or other means. 
Going-out-of-business sale means a sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that upon the disposal of the stock of goods on hand, the business will cease and be discontinued including, but not limited to, the following sales: adjuster's; adjustment; alteration; assignee's; bankrupt; benefit of administrator's; benefit or creditors'; benefit or trustees; building coming down; closing; creditor's; committee; creditor's end; executor's; final days; forced out; forced out of business; insolvents'; last days; lease expires; liquidation; loss of lease; mortgage sale; receiver's; trustee's quitting business. 
Goods means any goods, wares, merchandise or other property capable of being the object of a sale regulated under this article. 
Removal of business sale means a sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that the person conducting the sale will cease and discontinue business at the place of sale upon disposal of the stock of goods on hand and will then move to and resume business at a new location in the city, or will then continue business from other existing locations in the city. 
(Code 1982, § 5-206(2)) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 50-243. - Persons exempted. 
The provisions of this article shall not apply to or affect the following persons: 
(1)  Persons acting pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(2)  Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials. 
(3)  Duly licensed auctioneers selling at auctions. 
(4)  Any publisher of a newspaper, magazine or other publication who publishes in good faith any advertisement, without knowledge of its false, deceptive or misleading character, or without knowledge that the provisions of this article have not been complied with. 
(Code 1982, § 5-206(3)) 
Sec. 50-244. - License application. 
Application for a license under this article shall contain the following additional information: 
(1)  The true name and address of the owner of the goods to be the object of the sale, if other than the applicant; 
(2)  The true name and address of the person from whom such owner purchased the goods to be sold and the price therefor, and if not purchased, the manner of such acquisition; 
(3)  A description of the place where such sale is to be held; 
(4)  The nature of the occupancy, whether by lease or sublease, and the effective date of termination of such occupancy; 
(5)  The dates on which and the period of time in which the sale is to be conducted; 
(6)  A full and complete statement of the facts in regard to the sale, including the reasons for the urgent and expeditious disposal of goods thereby and the manner in which the sale will be conducted; 
(7)  The means to be employed in advertising such sale, together with the proposed content of any advertisement; and 
(8)  A complete and detailed inventory of the goods to be sold at such sale, as disclosed by the applicant's records. Such inventory shall be attached to and become a part of the required application. All goods included in such inventory shall have been purchased by the applicant for resale on bona fide orders without cancellation privileges, and shall not comprise goods purchased on consignment. 
(Code 1982, § 5-206(4)) 
Sec. 50-245. - License fee established. 
The business license fee for each person conducting a sale regulated by the provisions of this section shall be $50.00, or set by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1982, § 5-206(5)) 
Sec. 50-246. - Restriction on license issuance. 
No license shall be issued to any person who has held a sale, as regulated under this article, at the location stated in the application within one year from the date of such application. 
(Code 1982, § 5-206(6)) 
Sec. 50-247. - Conditions of license issuance. 
A license shall be issued under this article on the following terms: 
(1)  Nature of sale. The license shall authorize only the one type of sale described in the application at the location named therein. 
(2)  Saleable goods. The license shall authorize only the sale of goods described in the inventory attached to the application. 
(3)  Surrender of general license. Upon being issued a license under this article for a going-out-of-business sale, the licensee shall surrender to the city clerk all other business licenses he may hold at that time applicable to the location and goods covered by the application for a license under this article. 
(4)  Restricted location. Where a person applying for a license under this article operates more than one place of business, the license issued shall apply only to the one store or branch specified in the application. 
(5)  Nontransferability. Any license provided for in this article shall not be assignable or transferable. 
(Code 1982, § 5-206(7)) 
Sec. 50-248. - Duties of licensee. 
A licensee under this article shall: 
(1)  Adhere to inventory. Make no additions, whatsoever, during the period of the licensed sale, to the stock of goods set forth in the inventory attached to the application for license. 
(2)  Advertise properly. Refrain from employing any untrue, deceptive or misleading advertising. 
(3)  Adhere to advertising. Conduct the licensed sale in strict conformity with any advertising or publicity incident thereto. 
(4)  Keep duplicate inventory. Keep available at the place of sale a duplicate copy of the inventory submitted with the application and present such duplicate copy to inspecting officials upon request. 
(5)  Segregate non-inventoried goods. Keep any other goods separate and apart from the goods listed in the filed inventory as being objects of sale and make such distinction clear to the public by placing tags on all inventoried goods in and about the place of sale, apprising the public of the status of all such goods. 
(Code 1982, § 5-206(8)) 
Secs. 50-249—50-280. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - JUNK DEALERS AND JUNKYARDS 

Sec. 50-281. - License required. 
Each junk dealer, as such term is defined in section 50-282, who does business within this municipality shall be required to obtain a license from the city clerk in the manner specified in this article. 
(Code 1982, § 5-209(1)) 
Sec. 50-282. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Business premises or premises means the area of a junkyard as described in a junk dealer's license or application for license, as provided for in this article. 
Junk means old iron, steel, brass, copper, tin, lead or other base metals; old cordage, ropes, rags, fibers or fabrics; old rubber; old bottles or other glass; bones; wastepaper and other waste or discarded material which might be prepared to be used again in some form; and motor vehicles, no longer used as such, to be used for scrap metal or stripping of parts; but "junk" shall not include materials or objects accumulated by a person as byproducts, waste or scraps from the operation of his own business, or materials or objects held and used by a manufacturer as an integral part of his own manufacturing processes. 
Junk dealer means a person who operates a junkyard, as defined in this section, within the city. 
Junkyard means a yard, lot or place, covered or uncovered, outdoors or in an enclosed building, containing junk as defined in this section, upon which occurs one or more acts of buying, keeping, dismantling, processing, selling or offering for sale any such junk, in whole units or by parts, for a business or commercial purpose, whether or not the proceeds from such act or acts are to be used for charity. 
(Code 1982, § 5-209(2)) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 50-283. - License application. 
Application for a license under this article shall be made as provided in this chapter except that such application shall contain the following additional information: 
(1)  Trade names used during the previous five years by the applicant and each person signing the application, along with the locations of prior establishments; 
(2)  Names and addresses of employers of each person signing the application during the previous five years; 
(3)  The name, residence address, and telephone number of each person employed or intended to be employed in the business as of the time the application is filed; 
(4)  A sketch of the actual premises to be used in connection with the business, giving distances in feet and showing adjoining roads, property lines, buildings and uses; and 
(5)  A description of the materials with which any buildings to be used in connection with the licensed business are or are to be made; a sketch giving distances, showing the location of such buildings on the business premises; and a diagram or plan giving distances and heights, showing floors, exits, entrances, windows, ventilators and walls. 
(Code 1982, § 5-209(4)) 
Sec. 50-284. - Review of license application. 
No action on any application for a license to operate a junkyard shall be taken by the city council until the planning commission has reviewed such application and forwarded its recommendation thereon to the clerk in the manner specified in this article. 
(Code 1982, § 5-209(5)) 
Sec. 50-285. - License fee established. 
The annual business license fee for each junk dealer doing business in this municipality shall be on file in the clerk's office. 
(Code 1982, § 5-209(5)) 
Sec. 50-286. - General operating requirements. 
The following general operating requirements shall apply to all junk dealers licensed in accordance with the provisions of this article: 
(1)  The junkyard, together with things kept therein, shall at all times be maintained in a sanitary condition. 
(2)  No space not covered by the license shall be used in the licensed business. 
(3)  No water shall be allowed to stand in any place on the premises in such manner as to afford a breeding place for mosquitoes. 
(4)  No weeds shall be permitted to attain a height of more than four inches. 
(5)  No garbage or other waste liable to give off a foul odor or attract vermin shall be kept on the premises; nor shall any refuse of any kind be kept on the premises, unless such refuse is junk as defined herein and is in use in the licensed business. 
(6)  No junk shall be allowed to rest upon or protrude over any public street, walkway, curb or become scattered or blown off the business premises. 
(7)  Junk shall be stored in piles not exceeding ten feet in height and shall be arranged to permit easy access to all such junk for firefighting purposes. 
(8)  No combustible material of any kind not necessary or beneficial to the licensed business shall be kept on the premises; nor shall the premises be allowed to become a fire hazard. 
(9)  Gasoline and oil shall be removed from any scrapped engines or vehicles on the premises. 
(10)  No junk or other material shall be burned on the premises in any incinerator not meeting the requirements of the building code; and no junk or other material shall be burned on the premises in the open except in accordance with the provisions of section 22-32. 
(11)  No noisy processing of junk or other noisy activity shall be carried on in connection with the licensed business on any Sunday, Christmas, Thanksgiving, or at any time between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(12)  The area on the premises where junk is kept (other than indoors) shall be enclosed, except for entrances and exits, with a solid, vertical wall or fence of a minimum height of eight feet measured from ground level. The fence or wall shall not contain any poster or advertising of any kind excepting one sign of the licensee not exceeding four by eight feet in size. Entrances and exits shall not be wider or more numerous than reasonably necessary for the conduct of the licensed business. 
(13)  The licensee shall permit inspection of the business premises by any police officer at any reasonable time. 
(14)  No junkyard shall be allowed to become a nuisance; nor shall any junkyard be operated in such manner as to become injurious to the health, safety or welfare of the community or of any residents close by. 
(Code 1982, § 5-209(6)) 
Sec. 50-287. - Records. 
Each acquisition of junk shall be recorded in a permanent type register kept on the business premises, giving the name and residence address of the person from whom the acquisition was made, a description of the junk acquired, and the date of the transaction. Such data shall be held available for inspection by any police officer. 
(Code 1982, § 5-209(7)) 
Sec. 50-288. - Minors. 
No junk dealer shall have any business dealings as a junk dealer with a minor, nor shall a junk dealer's license be issued to a minor, nor shall a junk dealer employ a minor to assist him in his business. 
(Code 1982, § 5-209(8)) 
Sec. 50-289. - Stolen goods. 
Every junk dealer who shall receive or be in possession of any goods, articles or things of value which may have been lost or stolen shall upon demand produce such article or thing to any member of the police department for examination. 
(Code 1982, § 5-209(9)) 
Sec. 50-290. - Vehicles. 
Every vehicle used by a junk dealer in the conduct of his business shall bear thereon in legible characters the name and address of the owner and proprietor thereof.
